loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina T., who lives in the village of Barangay Doldol, Valladolid, Negros Occidental, is 54 years old and has been a widow for five years. She has four adult children who are 24 to 32 years old. Two of her children were able to finish college, the third also went to college but stopped. They already have their own families. The youngest is a high school graduate and now works in a factory in Manila and also sends money home. Regina earns a living by running her small general store. Regina's general store has been supplementing her family's income for over thirty years. With her husband's income, the general store's earnings provided for the extras that her family needed; the family totally depended on her husband's income. The sudden death of her husband five years ago left the family bereft and at a loss. The drastic drop in their family income pushed Regina to increase her income potential. This is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 - so that she could get additional capital to expand the operations of her general store so that she could increase her income, enough to support her family. With the cooperation of her children and her own efforts, Regina survived that crisis and, with the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, and five years later, Regina is now able to earn PHP 9,000 from her general store - which is enough to support her household expenses and stay independent. In her previous loan she borrowed Php 19,500 that she used as additional working capital for her general store. She paid off that loan in weekly installments for a set period without any delays until she was able to fully repay the principal amount. Now she is borrowing for her 13th loan the same amount of Php 19,500 which she intends to invest in expanding her business. The income from it will be used as savings for future emergencies. Regina is very thankful because she is given an opportunity to improve her life with the help of NWTF-Project Dungganon and with the help of our Lord Jesus Christ because He gives her the strength and courage to face the trials in life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn T. started selling fresh bananas as well as cooking bananacue (bananas fried with caramelized sugar) in 1993. She is 53 years old and married to Ricardo T., who is a farmer. The couple have seven children ranging in age from school children to young adults. She lives in the village of Brgy. San Isidro, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental.

Evelyn knows that her husband works hard to support the family but it is not always enough. As a farmer, his production is dependent on so many external factors including the weather. That’s why she wants to help her husband, even in a small way. Her additional income can help defray some of the family's expenses and, if she is able to earn more, she wants her seven children to finish their studies.

Her income has helped pay for their daily expenses and, inspired by the independence this venture has given her, Evelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 so that she could access additional capital and expand her business activities. With her new capital, she opened a general store and the combined earnings of her business activities has been providing a stable income for her family. She now earns an average monthly income of 8,000 Philippine pesos.

Her last loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos was used as additional working capital for her bananacue and general store business. She has fully repaid the loan without any delays in any of the weekly installments. Now on her 17th loan cycle, she is borrowing 12,000 Philippine pesos to purchase additional inventory for her general store. She will reserve some money as revolving capital for her bananacue business. The income from this loan will be used to pay for the tuition fees of her children.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: For a general store and bananacue business

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en: Mary Grace S. lives in the village of Barangay San Antonio, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She is 29 years old, married to Roger S., who is a tricycle driver, and also serves as one of the elected Barangay (village) Councilors. The couple is blessed with two young children who are 8 and 9 years old. Their common dream is to improve their business, be able to send their children to school and have them graduate with bachelor degrees, and to be able to buy a truck so that they can earn a good living for their family. Even before she married, Mary Grace already had a general store which helped her support her parents. When she got married, she knew that she had to earn more to continue helping her parents as well as help her husband provide for their family. In 2002, to get additional capital, Mary Grace joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could expand her business operations. With more capital to use, she is able to maintain a wider inventory for her general store, which effectively earns her a bigger monthly income, which is now averaging PHP 14,000 per month. Mary Grace borrowed PHP 22,000 in her previous loan, which she used as additional working capital for her general store. Now that she has fully repaid that loan, she is borrowing PHP 24,000 for her 17th loan to use as working capital for her general store so that she can offer a wider variety of goods to her regular customers. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina M. believes that poverty is not a hindrance to improving the living conditions of every individual. Armed with that philosophy, she is well on her way to improving the life of her family through her faith and hard work. She is 41 years old and married to Robert M. who helps her run the business. The couple has three very young children and they live in the village of Brgy. Alianza, Bago City, Negros Occidental.

Before Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, she already had a general store which helped her husband meet the needs of the family. But then, as an entrepreneur, she aimed to expand her business. This is why, in June 2004, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access additional capital for her general store. With the help of her loans, she has been able to improve her general store, expanding her product lines to include different kinds of household commodities and a wider variety of products. She has continued to use her subsequent loans to expand her business and has put up a retail business where people in her community can buy rice – the staple food for Filipinos. Her combined business income is now 10,000 Philippine pesos per month.

For her 14th loan cycle, she borrowed 5,000 Philippine pesos as additional working capital for her general store and rice retailing business. It was fully repaid on time without any delays. Now she is requesting her 15th loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos to buy additional items for her general store. Whatever income she makes will be saved for the education of her children and for house repairs.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: To buy additional items for her general store

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites B. is 39 years old and married to William B. who is a laborer in an Hacienda (sugarcane plantation) in their place. They have four young children who are presently attending school, and are aged between 6 and 19 years old. The family lives in the village of Sitio Lanipga, Carabalan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Marites is helping her husband earn a living for their young family because she knows that, as a laborer in an Hacienda, he receives very low wages that could not even support the daily needs of their family. Because of this life situation, she tried to look for an alternative where she could help her husband. She put up a very small general store so that she could supplement her husband's income and help support her family. As the business did well, Marites realized that there was an opportunity to expand her business - she only needed an infusion of capital to achieve it. That’s why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in January 2002. Her business continued to do well and, with the help of her loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she was able to acquire a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) piece of land which her husband planted with sugarcane to earn extra for the family. Now, their combined business ventures earns them a net monthly income of PHP 5,000 which they use to support the family expenses and the education of their children. Previously, Marites borrowed PHP 19,000 for her 11th loan, which she used as additional working capital for her general store. This time around, she is borrowing the same amount of PHP 19,000 to be used for her general store and for their 1-hectare sugarcane farm. The income from it is already pegged to buy a new motorcycle so that they can increase their income potential even further. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store and sugarcane farm

loans.name: Emelinda

texts.en:
Emelinda G. lives in the village of Tabao 13, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. Her one big dream is to improve her family's standard of living, to have enough capital to expand her business, and to prepare her four children for a better future. Her dream started to become a reality when she became a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon.

Emelinda is 52 years old and is married to Artimio G., who helps her manage their business. They have four children, aged 22 to 29 years old. Two of their children already have their own families and the other two still live at home -- one works as a seaman and other is a student.

Emelinda and Artimio started out selling pork to retail customers. They bought pigs and had them butchered, and then her husband delivered the pork meat to various meat shops on consignment. This earns them a good living, but they are always on the lookout for other business opportunities, so in 2000 she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon and opened a new business selling spare parts and electronic gadgets. 

They continued with their pork retail business, earning a combined monthly income of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). They use their income to support their household expenses and pay for school tuition, and they have some left over for savings. Emelinda had a previous loan of 29,500 PHP, which she used for both her spare parts and her pork retail business. She repaid this loan in full within its loan term and without any delays. She is now borrowing for her 23rd cycle the same amount of 29,500 PHP. She will use this loan as additional working capital and to purchase additional spare parts inventory. 

In the accompanying picture, Emelinda is shown in her spare parts and electronics business with her husband in the background.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
N. Nguyễn Thị is a 47 year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  N. is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chờ 01.

N. is married and has 2 adult children.  To making a living, N. operates a family member's business venture operating a service-based business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members.  N. has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3.800.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  N. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.704.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase equipment to improve the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 7.392.000 VND which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service.  The loan will be the 4th loan she has taken from SEDA.  N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Đặng Thị N. is a 49 year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.

2.  Lê Thị Quý is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.

3.  Đặng Thị N. T. is a 28 year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.

4.  Nguyễn Thị H. is a 54 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


N. Nguyễn Thị (20201030001) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  N. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phố Chờ 01 (1).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ làm tóc & làm đẹp cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  N. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, N. kiếm được khoảng 3.800.000 VND.  Vào 2007, N. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  N. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.704.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thiết bị để cải thiện công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Đặng Thị N. (20201030002) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


2.  Lê Thị Quý (20201030003) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  Đặng Thị N. T. (20201030004) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201030005) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia S. was already a retired teacher when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon. She is 64 years old and is retired from her teaching profession but is still very active. She is married to Angelo S., Jr. and they currently operate their own business producing feed out of cassava mixed with some ingredients.  They also make cassava chips, cassava granules and even cassava powder. The couple have 4 children, 2 are already married and 2 are still single and they have 3 grandchildren. They live in Marietta Village, Brgy. Taloc, Bago City, Negros Occidental. 

Her immediate dream is to be able to buy a new machine that will enable them to produce cassava chips and other cassava-based food products more easily.
	
In business one must be a step ahead in terms of strategies and technology. To stay ahead, Letty and her husband needed additional capital, which is the reason why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001. With the infusion of new capital, they were able to survive stiff competition and Letty also supplemented their family income by selling appliances on commission basis as a sideline. With the help of the loans, they were able to expand their operations and even expanded their product distribution to other areas, getting regular customers as far as the province of Iloilo.

Previously, she borrowed Php 29,000 to use as additional capital for her business and as usual the loan was fully paid in full and on time. This contributed to her maintaining her good credit performance. Now for her 18th cycle loan she intends to borrow the same amount of Php 29,000 for her business of producing feeds and cassava-based products. 

The accompanying picture shows Letecia and her husband in their business site with some of their cassava inventory packed in sacks. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase brand new machinery for production & Business expansion

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora D. is a hardworking mother and a good entrepreneur who is always looking for a great opportunity to earn more for her family and for the education of her children. She lives in the village of Prk Paraiso, Brgy Taloc, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She is 56 years old and married. Her husband, Rafael D., manages their 1.25-hectare rice farm. He also helps Leonora run their other business ventures. Together, Rafael and Leonora have 5 children, 3 of whom are already married. The other 2 are still single and live at home. Leonora has 5 grandchildren. 

Leonora buys and sells rice because rice production is prevalent in their community. Her trading business was earning her a good income, but when the opportunity to join NWTF-Project Dungganon came, she did not hesitate, and expanded her business activities to include pig fattening in 2001. Leonora treated this new business as a way to secure additional income. Every time she sold a hog, she would save a portion of the proceeds in her emergency fund. She also used the income to pay for her children's tuition. With the added income from hog-raising she was able to earn an average monthly income of 30,000 Philippine pesos, or about $630 US, good income that provides a comfortable living for her family.

Because Leonora is a responsible businesswoman, repays loans well, is very responsible and has good leadership qualities, she was elected as a center chief by other members of NWTF-PD. She wants to prove and teach other members that being a hardworking person helps improve one's standing in life. Even with the added responsibilities, Leonora continues to do well in her business activities and is a good center chief.

For her previous loan she borrowed 25,000 pesos, or about $525, as additional capital for her rice trading business and pig fattening venture. The loan was paid in weekly installments and was repaid without delay. For this loan, Leonora's 16th, she is requesting 29,000 pesos, or about $625, to be used as additional capital for her businesses. Income resulting from the loan will be used for the education of her children and daily household expenses.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day to surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: additional capital for her pig fattening & rice business

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
"C. Nguyễn Thị is a 54 year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. C. is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chờ 1 nhóm 03 (3).

C. is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, C. owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general services to local community members. C. has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000,000 Vietnam dong (VND) a month from these activities.

In 2007, C. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. C. has successfully repaid a previous SEDA loan of 4,704, 000 VND. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

She is now requesting a new loan of 7,392,000 VND, which she will use to purchase materials needed to expand the services her business provides. This will be the fourth loan C. has taken out from SEDA. C. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

Nguyễn Thị V. is a 48 year-old woman who is requesting a loan of 6,496,000 VND to support her business operating a specialized retail store. 3. Đặng Thị H. is a 37 year-old woman who is requesting a loan of 4,704,000 VND to support her service-based business. 4. Nguyễn Thị N. is a 41 year-old woman who is requesting a loan of 6,496,000 VND to support her service-based business. 5. Đặng Thị

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Range Group

texts.en:
R. F., age 45, is married with three children, ages 18, 12 and 4. He has had a second-hand clothing business for one year now. He works daily from 8am until 6pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $227.

This will be R.’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He hopes for a loan to increase the stock of the second-hand clothes he sells. 
	
R. will share this loan with his loan group, Range, which consists of 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, R. is first on the right.

loans.use: Increase second-hand clothing stock

loans.name: Huong's Group

texts.en:
Hường Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090081) is 32 years old.  She has 2 children who are going to school. She makes steamed rolls made of rice flour to sell. Her family life is difficult, so she wants to access loans to develop economically and so her family can enjoy a better life.

She has received loans from a Microfund organization for 4 years and repaid on time. She is a group leader. She has a monthly income of about 3,000.000 VND. This time, she wants to borrow 5,450.000 VND (or 300 USD) to buy rice to make steamed rolls made of rice flour.

There are 4 other Fund participants in her group:

Nở Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090082) is 39 years old. She is farming and breeding chickens. She wants to borrow 5,450.000 VND (or 300 USD) to buy more chickens to raise.

Quyết Thị Lê (id: 010117090084) is 32 years old. She wants to borrow 4,578.000 VND (or 250 USD) to breed poultry.

Nhàn Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090083) is 38 years old. She sells clothes in the market. She wants to borrow 5,450.000 VND (or 300 USD) to invest in her shop.

Ninh Thị Đào (id: 010117090095) is 44 years old. She wants to borrow 3,706.000 VND (or 200 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.use: To buy rice to make steamed rolls made of rice flour.

loans.name: Aisha's Group

texts.en: N. Aisha is a friendly, hard working and devoted lady, and the leader of her lending group in Ganyana. She is a farmer, selling farm produce to her customers in the Busabala Central market, as well as a fish monger, selling both fresh and dry fish to her customers at the landing site. She is 38 years old and has been involved in both her businesses for quite a long time. She is grateful that the loans, in addition to her hard work, have helped her boost her businesses. Aisha has been able to educate her children, plus securing household items and land for them, so that they will not lack so much in the future. At the moment, Aisha needs a loan to recapitalize her businesses for increased profits.

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale and employing manpower on her farm.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
T. Nguyễn Thị (20201030012) is a 39-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  T. is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by SEDA, a Kiva field partner.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chờ 1 nhóm 02 (2).

T. is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business selling soft drinks in the local community.  She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately $147 a month from these activities.

In 2007, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.256.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.048.000 VND which will be used, as before, to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be her fourth loan from SEDA.  T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201030006) is a 69-year-old female who is requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.

2.  Nguyễn Thị N. (20201030009) is a 46-year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

3.  Nguyễn Thị C. (20201030008) is a 26-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector selling home products.

4.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201030010) is a 27-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector providing recycling services.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide micro-finance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


T.  Nguyễn Thị (20201030012) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  T.  là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phố Chờ 1 nhóm 02 (2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các loại nước ngọt trong cộng đồng địa phương.  T.  thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, T.  kiếm được khoảng 2.600.000 VND.  Vào 2007, T.  đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  T.  đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.256.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.048.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201030006) là 69 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


2.  Nguyễn Thị N. (20201030009) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  Nguyễn Thị C. (20201030008) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán hàng gia dụng.


4.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201030010) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ tái chế.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Milly's Group

texts.en: K. Milly is the leader of her lending group in Kampala. She is a widow with four children, two of whom are orphans. Ever since her husband died, she has taken up the responsibility of caring for her children and paying their school fees. Two are in candidate classes and the others are in lower grades. Loans have helped Milly reinvest in her salon business. She has purchased more hair extensions, hair chemicals, a hair dryer and so on, and these have helped her build up her salon and attract more customers. Milly needs a loan to help restock her salon with more items for increased income.

loans.use: To restock her salon with more items like hair chemicals, braids, weaves and others.

loans.name: Ivone

texts.pt:
Ivone D. Conceição nasceu em Chokwe, Província de Gaza, tem 44 anos de idade, divorciaD. e mãe de 02 filhos com 23 e 24 anos de idade, todos já não vão à escola. Estudou ate 10ªclasse, parou de estudar porque teve que começar a trabalhar muito cedo para responder as despesas caseiras para sustento. Vive na casa própria em Boane e para alem dos filhos sustenta também os pais, enviando dinheiro mensalmente.

Saiu de Chokwe para Maputo quando se casou ha 25 anos. Actualmente é negociante e dona do negocio há 06 anos. O produto que mais vende é a loiça e outros utensílios domésticos os quais compra por 2.500.00MT e vende a 3.000.00MT e faz compras três vezes por mês.

Nunca teve credito com outras instituições bancárias, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma vizinha. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo nesta instituição no valor de 15.200.00MT com o qual pretende comprar Produtos de Mercearia e loiça de cozinha tensilios domésticos e outros para venD..

Tem como objectivo deste empréstimo, aumentar o seu rendimento através de aquisição de mais produtos para o seu negocio. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos a fim de adquirir uma viatura.
texts.en:
Ivone D. Conceição is originally from Chokwe, Mozambique. She is 44, divorced and the mother of two children ages 23 and 24, who are both out of school. She finished 10th grade but had to drop school to start working and support her family. She lives in her own house in Maputo and besides her children she also supports her parents, sending them money every month. She owns her own business selling kitchen utensils. She is asking for a 15.200,00MT (U$550) loan that she'll use to buy more merchandise to resell at her store.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of kitchen utensils for reselling

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
B. Amina is 42-years-old and the leader of her lending group in Bushenyi. She is a friendly, determined and very hard working lady with a business of selling matooke (green cooking bananas) in Kizinda for eight years. Her matooke is mostly for home consumption since she has not yet grown enough to sell on a wholesale basis.

Amina is married with five children between the ages of 11 and 23. The profits she makes every week help to take care of her family plus to pay her children’s school fees. She works hard to ensure that all her children become educated to the University level for self-sustenance.

She started out as a farmer, selling her produce directly from her garden, but now has the opportunity of selling to the general market at a much higher price. Over the years, she has been able to create a large customer base, and in the future, Amina would like to be able to transport her produce to Kampala using her own truck, although she does not own one at the moment. She needs a loan to be able to increase her capital for more income.

loans.use: To buy more matooke for resale.

loans.name: Ana Rabeca

texts.pt:
Ana M. nasceu em Maputo, província de Maputo, tem 35 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 03 filhos de 19, 14 e 11 anos de idade, os dois mais novos e que vão à escola. Estudou ate 6ªclasse parou por falta de condições por parte dos pais. Vive na casa própria e para alem dos filhos sustenta também o irmão que vive com ela.

Nunca mudou de cidade, sempre viveu com a família no Bairro Khongolote, é comerciante permanente há 12 anos, faz 08 horas diárias e não tem nenhum empregado. Aprendeu a fazer o negocio com seus pais há 12 anos. O seu rendimento mensal varia de 10.000,00MT a 12.000,00MT com o qual sustenta a família e poupa algum para investir na sua obra.

Este e o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku, mas já trabalhou com outra instituição de credito denominada FDM onde se beneficiou de três financiamentos para reforçar o seu negocio. 
Conheceu a Hluvuku através da oficial de credito da mesma tendo aproximado e solicita o presente empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00MT, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, ferro, areia e outros).

Pretende concluir o seu empréstimo sem problemas, para poder aceder a mais créditos a fim de concluir a sua obra e compra de uma Geleira.
texts.en:
Ana M. is from Maputo, Mozambique. She's 35 and a single mother of three children aged 19, 14 and 11. The two younger ones are students. She finished 6th grade but had to drop school because her parents could no longer support her. She lives in her own house and in the top of her children she also supports a brother who lives with them. She's been working as a salersperson for the past 12 yeras. She works 8 hours a day and has no employees. She learned the business with her parents. Her monthly income varies between 10.000,00MT and 12.000,00MT (U$340 to U$400), money that she uses to support her family and finish building her house. This is her first loan and she's asking for 15.000,00MT (U$525) in order to buy construction supplies (cement, iron, sand and others). She plans on paying this without a problem so she can ask for other loans to finish the house and buy a freezer.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Ahmad Sha Group

texts.en:
There are three members in this group led by A. Sha.They requested a group loan 42,000 Afghani.

A. Sha is a married man with four children: three daughters and one son. Two daughters are married, one daughter is in class six, and his son is a university student. A. Sha has a laundry and has taken the loan to purchase necessary materials for his business to make his business grow.

A. Sabor, who is a single boy, has a general store. There are six members in his family and he is the only person who supports them.

Malleha wants to take a loan for her tailoring business in her house. She wants to buy three new machines for her business and bring a new change to her business.

They are very happy with this loan in Afghanistan which improves their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials for his laundry

loans.name: Sabino Antonio

texts.pt:
Sabino António T. nasceu em Maputo cidade capital, tem 33 anos de idade casado e pai de 2 filhos de 9 e 4 anos de idade, o mais velho vai à escola. Fez 12ª classe, vive na casa própria, com a sua família e sustenta seus pais e um filho adoptado.

Nunca saiu da cidade, actualmente trabalha como professor na casa do Gaiato e ganha salário no Ministério da Educação e nesta escola privada (casa do Gaiato). Foi formado pelo instituto de formação de professores de Namaacha. Neste emprego ganha cerca de 12.000.00MT por mês, com o qual sustenta sua família e poupa algum no Banco comercial BIM (Banco Internacional de Moçambique).

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através do oficial de credito desta sucursal, este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00MT para compra de material de construção (cimento, pedra e portões). Os valores anteriores foram de 12.500,00MT e 15.000,00MT, todos para a mesma actividade, compra de material de construção.

Propõe se a pagar o empréstimo sem problemas para poder aceder a mais créditos com objectivo de concluir a sua casa e adquirir uma viatura para facilitar o transporte de uma escola para outra.
texts.en:
Sabino António T. is a native of Maputo, Mozambique. He is 33 years old, married and the father of two children aged 9 and 4, the older one goes to school. He finished 12th grade and became a teacher. He teaches at a private school called Gaiato and also works for the Ministry of Education. He makes around 12.000,00MT (U$410) per month, which he uses to support his family and save. He lives at his own house with his family and also supports his parents and an adopted child. He's asking for a 15.000,00MT (U$525) loan in order to buy construction supplies to finish building his house. He hopes to pay this without a problem so he can ask for other loans in the future and buy a car.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Venancio Alberto

texts.pt:
Venâncio J. nasceu em Mocuba, província da Zambézia, no centro de Moçambique, tem 25 anos de idade, solteiro, não tem nenhum filho. Frequenta 2º ano na Universidade Pedagógica. Vive na casa própria e não sustenta ninguém.

Saiu em 1990 de Mocuba para Maputo a fim de dar continuidade com seus estudos, actualmente trabalha como professor na escola Secundaria Josina Machel desde 2008 e tem um horário das 12h as 17h30minh. Foi formado no Instituto Agrário de Boane (IAB) em 2007, aufere um salário mensal de 4.382,00MT com o qual custeia despesas escolares e investe na sua obra de construção de uma casa própria.

Nunca trabalhou com nenhuma instituição de credito, conheceu a Hluvuku através de um amigo. Este e o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000,00MT com o qual pretende comprar material de construção, cimento, tinta, areia e outros.

Compromete-se a pagar bem o empréstimo para poder aceder a outros financiamentos para concluir a sua obra e compra de eletrodomésticas.
texts.en:
Venâncio J. was born in Mocuba, Zambézia province, in central Moçambique. He is 25 years old, single and has no children. He is on the second year at the University Pedagógica. He lives in his own house and does not economically supports anybody.

In 1990 he left Mocuba to Maputo in order to continue his studies. Currently he works as a teacher at the secondary school Josina Machel. He has been working there since 2008 and works from 12:00 a.m to 05:30 p.m. He graduated from the Agrário Boane Instutite (IAB) in 2007. He earns a monthly salary of MZN 4,382.00, with which he pays school expenses and invests in the construction of his own house.

He has never worked with another credit institution. He learned about Hluvuku through a friend. This is his first loan, of MZN 10,000.00, with which he intends to buy construction materials such as cement, paints, sand and others.

He hopes to pay this without a problem so he can get other loans to conclude the construction and buy house appliances.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construcion materials (cement, and others)

loans.name: Filomena Juliao

texts.pt:
Filomena M. nasceu em Chipongo, distrito de Massinga, província de Inhambane, no sul de Moçambique, tem 34 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 03 filhos de 15, 09 e 06 anos de idade, todos vão à escola. Fez 7ªclasse parou por causa da gravidez precoce. Vive na casa própria e para alem dos filhos sustenta os 05 irmãos que vivem com ela.

Saiu de Massinga em 1989 com a mãe, quando perdeu o pai para se juntar ao irmão mais velho que já vivia na cidade de Maputo. Actualmente é comerciante e dona do negocio a mais de 09 anos. Trabalha sozinha das 06h às 18h, aprendeu a fazer o negocio por iniciativa própria e tem um rendimento mensal de 5.000,00MT a 6.000,00MT com o qual consegue poupar para investir no seu negocio.

Nunca trabalhou com outras instituições de créditos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua prima que também e cliente da instituição. Este e o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 11.000,00MT para compra e venda de roupa diversa, nova para meninas e senhoras. 
Compromete-se a pagar bem o empréstimo para poder aceder a outros financiamentos e construir um murro na sua casa.
texts.en:
Filomena M. was born in Chipongo, district of Massinga, province of Inhambane, in the south of Mozambique, she is 34 years old, and is married and has 3 children who are 15, 9 and 6 years old, they all go to school. Filomena stopped studying when she was in 7th grade due to her pregnancy. She lives in her own house and besides her kids, she supports her 5 brothers who live with her. She left Massinga in 1989 with her mother, when she lost her father, and they joined her oldest brother who already lived in Maputo. She owns a business for the last 9 years. She works by herself from 6 am to 6 pm, she learned it by herself and started it from her own initiative and has a monthly profit of 5.000MT to 6.000MT and she is able to save and re-invest on her business. She never worked with another credit institutions, she learned about Hluvuku thru her cousin who is a client too. This is her first loan for 10.000MT to buy and sell diverse clothes, new clothes for ladies and girls. She will pay well the loan in order to access to other loans and build a wall at her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell clothes

loans.name: Elly's Group

texts.en:
K. Elly is 61 years old and married with six children aged 12 to 24 years. He is a strong and hard-working man who also helps to take care of four orphans.

Elly has a butcher shop in Kizinda town where he has been selling fresh meat for twenty years. He is grateful that, at the moment, he is able to make about $215 in profits each month. Elly says that he started as a helper for four years in his father’s butcher shop, and later started up his own, where he was buying meat in kilograms. He is happy that now he buys the whole animals for meat.

He has been successful because of the quality meat that he sells, as well as having good customer care. Elly says that there is a lot of competition in his business, but he believes this is no threat because of his good service.

He needs a loan to help buy a cow for meat.

loans.use: Buying a cow for meat.

loans.name: Arian Group

texts.en:
This is Arian group. The group is made up of three members and Shaima is the group leader. These three members have requested a group loan of 40,000 Afghani.

Shaima is married and has three children: two sons and one daughter. She embroiders in her house. Now, with the Kiva loan, she wants to buy a new sewing machine and wants to start her business in its new way to support her husband and children.

Nazia, who is the second member of Arian group, has a tailoring business. Through its income she supports her family members and her purpose of getting loan is to expand her business.

The last member is Taj Baroo who is a quilt maker.

They all would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The client is 44 years old and single. She lives with her old mother and is the breadwinner for her family. She has been a tailor for ten years and has acquired a great deal of experience in the job. She is doing tailoring in order to make a living for herself and her mother. She requested this loan in order to buy a new sewing and knitting machine as well as some fabric and other supplies.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing and knitting machine, fabric and supplies

loans.name: Agnes' Group

texts.en:
N. Agnes is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 32 years old and married with four children aged 3 to 14, all of whom are in school.

Agnes has been a farmer in Lwera, Nakisunga for ten years, selling her own produce. Her main challenge is the lack of enough capital to boost her business. She is able to make $45 a week in profit, and this helps to run her home and to pay her children’s school fees. Agnes’ friendly nature has won her customers, and she would like to expand her business further. Since she is now renting, she hopes to build a family house in the future on a plot that she and her husband bought.

She needs a loan to help boost her business. The last growing season was not favorable to her, so she needs to buy more produce to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The client is married and has two children. He has been buying, selling, and repairing mobile phones for three years. He has requested this loan to buy new mobile phones in order to expand his business and better respond to the competition. This loan will help generate an income and improve his living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones

loans.name: Amid

texts.en: Amid was born in 1986. He lives in the Fuzuli region. This young man is single. Three years ago he started his cafe business. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy necessary things for his cafe.

loans.use: To buy necessary things for his cafe

loans.name: Norya Mayedagull Group

texts.en:
This is Norya MayedaG. group, made up of seven female members. Mayeda G. who is on the right is the group leader.

Mayeda G. is forty and married with four children, all of whom are school students. She is a bead worker. She is really interested in her work and through it she can support her family members.

Jamellah wants to take a loan for her bead-working business. She wants a new shop for her business and that is why she asked for the loan to be able to carry on her business in the way she wants.

Bibi Zahra and Fayeza both share a business with their husbands. They clean and package fresh fruit which their husbands sell in their shops.

Shokofa and Norya would like to take a loan for their carpet-weaving businesses. They would like to buy essential materials for their businesses and expand them as well.

Rayeza G. wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store.

All the group members hope that they will be successful and will be able to expand their businesses. Together, they requested a group loan of 98,000 Afghani. They admire this effective loan process.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for her bead-working business

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah N. is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 28 years old and a single mother of one child, with other siblings to take care of. Sarah is a hard working and friendly lady. She has been in the business of selling ladies’ clothing from the Kazinga trading centre for eight years.

Her business challenge is the seasonality of her business, the expensive rent and the excessive dust from the murram road (gravel) where her shop is located. She is a friendly lady and knows how to present herself well. Sarah has a dream of opening a large boutique in the future, as well as to continue developing herself and having a good life together with her child.

This is Sarah’s first loan with her group, and she would like to use it to purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and jewelry for resale.

loans.name: Razya Shabebe Group

texts.en:
The Razya Shabebe Group has four members. Razya is the group leader and works as a quilt sewer. She wants to purchase materials for her business.

Shabibi has a bakery and wants a loan to buy more wood for her bakery business.

Shar Aqa wants to take out a loan for his butchers shop and will use the loan to buy the necessary things for his business.

M. Temor is requesting a loan for his business of selling wood. He wants to expand the business and use his loan to purchase more materials.

All members of the group would like to receive a loan to grow their businesses. Finally, each member of the group thanks Kiva.

loans.use: To buy materials for their businesses

loans.name: Akbar

texts.en: Akbar has been in the house-repair business for four years. He was born in 1975 and is married with two children. The N. family lives in the Fuzuli region. Now Akbar needs a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business.

loans.use: to improve his business

loans.name: Mehraban Group

texts.en:
The Mehraban Group has three members. The first member and group leader is Rahela. Rahela is 45, married, and has four children. She is a tailor and works in her own house. She has organized a small room in which she does her sewing. She wants to take out a loan for the purpose of buying a new machine because she has had problems with the old one.

Farida wants to take out a loan for her husband’s general store in order to purchase the required materials for the store.

The last group member, Pari Khanum, wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a car repair shop.

They have requested a group loan of 30,000 AFN and would like to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is 41 years old, married, and the mother of three children. Her first child is in senior high school and the rest are in primary school.

Vida always works hard to meet her target, and because of that she has acquired lots of marketing and selling experience. She is a trader and sells spices and vegetables like tomatoes, onions, peppers and so on in the community market. She takes delivery of goods from the surrounding villages and retails them to her customers. She sells her goods from the top of an erected table.

She is requesting a loan to buy lots of carrots, tomatoes, onions and spices to upgrade her stock. Vida dreams of saving more in order to take care of her children's educational needs.

loans.use: To buy vegetables like carrots, tomatoes, onions, pepper etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old, is currently married, and is the mother of four children. All her children are currently in school.

Mary is determined to raise her business to a higher level through hard work, motivation and commitment. To achieve her dream, she does not play with business; she has been selling cosmetics with products like spray, powder, lip gloss, lingerie etc. and sells in the community market. She has been in business for six years now.

Mary says that the selling of cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her make a good income. She is so sure that your loan support will bring her to the desired results she expects.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is fifty-eight years old. He is married and is the father of thirteen children, some of whom are in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Mampong in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Solomon works to be able to provide for his family. He is a trader, selling provisions, and he farms as well. He procures the goods from nearby towns and sells in a store by the roadside in his community.

Solomon has been in business for some years now and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. He is hopeful to give his children the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 36 years old, is married, and is the mother of four children. All her children are in school.

Cecilia is a baker who has used flour for her production for ten years now. In spite of the challenges she faces. She bakes bread, cakes, meat pies, plantain chips, etc. and retails them to her customers. She supplies them by herself in the market center to her customers and people also take bulk delivery from her.

Cecilia’s only problem now has to do with adequate funds to buy raw materials as prices are going up. She requests a loan to buy stock like margarine, sugar, firewood, flour, etc., to remain in business and to increase her profit even as we approach Christmas season. With the loan she believes she can provide for her family and, most especially, her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her bakery

loans.name: Sadig Mirdjafar

texts.en: Sadig was born in 1986 and lives in Fuzuli region. This young man has been in the cattle-breeding business for five years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy four calves to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy four calves

loans.name: Humu

texts.en:
Humu is fifty-one years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both now adults and out of school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Mampong in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Humu works to support her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a food vendor, cooking and selling a local dish called ‘tuozafi’, or TZ for short. It is prepared from corn flour and served hot with soup. She procures the goods from nearby towns and sells by the roadside in the evenings.

Humu has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to procure the food items and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making tuozafi

loans.name: Khairidin

texts.en:
Khairidin is 51 years old and is married with 5 children. He opened his grocery 9 years ago. Khairidin provides his neighbors and occasional clients with products like bread, rice, sugar, meat, milk, and other staples. He tells us that thanks to his grocery’s early opening hours and the good service he offers his customers, he has been able to move forward with the business. Khairidin wants the loan to purchase more merchandise, such as tinned products, sweets, drinks, etc. He and his family appreciate your support in helping him improve his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON’s History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff to increase his range of goods for selling

loans.name: Rogull Zaya Jan Group

texts.en:
This is the Rogull Zaya J. Group. There are four members in this group, and the group leader is Rogull. She is married and has six children. Four of her daughters are in school and two daughters are married. She wants to take a loan for her embroidery business to buy a new embroidery machine in order to make higher quality work.

Mah Gull also wants to take a loan for her son who is in the business of selling cosmetics. He wants to expand and grow his business.

Zaya J. wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store to purchase the required materials for the store.

The last member is Shokorya who wants to take a loan for her tailoring business to make a new shop.

They have requested a group loan of 40,000 AFN in order to support their families.

loans.use: To buy a new embroidery machine

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is forty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Mampong in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Rose works to support her husband and provide for the family. She is a trader. She runs a provision store. Her store is by the roadside in her community. Rose procures the goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for some years now and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. Rose is hopeful about giving her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en: This young man has been in this business for 3 years. He teaches students to play the accordion. He lives in the Fuzuli region. Rashad was born in 1989, and he is single. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to improve his business.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.en:
Nuriddin is a hardworking person, and he makes an effort to give his 4 beloved children the best. He decided to stay in his homeland so that he could develop it, and now he carries out his everyday chores with a lot of love and affection as he feeds his animals. With experience gained over 8 years in the purchase and sale of cattle, he has been able to bring stability to his family. Nuriddin now would like to purchase cattle that can create more income for his large family. For this reason he requests $1,450 USD. Nuriddin thanks you very much for your love of the prodigal.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha is forty-three years old. She is married and has given birth to one child, now in school. She lives with her child and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Mampong in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to support her husband financially and provide for the family. Martha is a trader. She trades in cosmetics. She procures the goods from nearby towns and hawks to sell at the local market. She also treks to other communities to sell. Martha has been in business for some years now and is hopeful about giving her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is thirty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Mampong in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Rebecca works to help her husband to provide for the family. She is a petty trader. She runs a provisions store. Her store is by the roadside in her community.

Rebecca procures the goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy provisions for re-sale

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is thirty-five years old. She is married and has children. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Mampong in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Cecilia works to help her husband financially provide for the family. She is a petty trader. She sells cosmetics. Cecilia procures the goods from nearby towns and hawks to sell at the local market. She also treks to other communities to sell.

Cecilia has been in business for eleven years and wants a loan to expand her business. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Hurmatoy

texts.en:
K. Hurmatoy is a happy mother of three children. She is 29 years old and married. Hurmatoy is a teacher. Her salary is very small and that’s why she has been running her own grocery business. For six years she has been selling foodstuffs such as sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks, tea, coffee, and many others in her grocery store.

Hurmatoy’s wish is to expand her business, offering various types of foodstuffs to customers who pass through this market. She works with one aim in mind, to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children who are all the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts.

With this opportunity and with the immense love Hurmatoy feels as a mother and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of 6800 Somoni in order to increase the range of her goods. You can be an important link in the growth of this business by supporting Hurmatoy.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of foodstuffs to increase the range of  goods she offers

loans.name: Rosemond

texts.en:
Rosemond is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of three. Two of her kids are in school, and her last born is breastfeeding. She is an entrepreneur, dynamic and very dedicated to her work. She works hard to help her husband in taking care of the children.

Rosemond has been a supplier of palm oil for over nine years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts. She takes delivery of stock from nearby communities and supplies to food vendors to prepare their meals, among other customers. She also sells cereals in addition to the oil she sells.

It is her dream to achieve her goals through loan support. She wants to use this loan to buy more gallons of palm oil to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
M. Rustam is 34 years old. He is married with three adorable children. Rustam has always opted to make his life in his land and work hard and grow with it. That is why he decided to rear cows and dedicated himself to agriculture. He has been doing this kind of work for a very long time, for he comes from a family with an entirely agricultural background.

Today Rustam wishes to increase the number of his cattle and for this reason, he would like to buy calves with the hope of increasing his income and the well-being of his home with the innumerable benefits that these special little animals provide him. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 1900 USD. Extend your solidarity to Rustam so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves to expand the business

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is 46 years old and a married mother of four children, all of whom are in school. To support her household, she has been selling cereals such as beans, maize and groundnuts, to her loyal customers at the community market. She takes delivery of stock from Atebubu in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana, and retails it to her customers.

Regina says selling these products is very lucrative and, with ten years of experience, she can increase her market share. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to expand her inventory in order to make a good income. This will help her support her family, especially her children's education, and expand her business. Regina anticipates that her sales will increase as we approach Christmas. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of groundnuts, yams and beans

loans.name: Kassipin

texts.fr:
Agée de 47 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants Madame Kassipin Traoré vit  dans une famille polygame  avec  sa coépouse, son époux et leurs  enfants dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de  Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). Madame Kassipin n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école. Elle s’intéressa très vite aux activités génératrices de revenus, qu’elle appris auprès de sa maman. Après une vingtaine d’année d’expérience dans cette activité, elle a  une grande notoriété dans son secteur d’activité.  
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle en quantité et en qualité, madame n’a pas pris du temps pour faire  recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  depuis maintenant  3 ans.  Après   4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et un prêt individuel, tous remboursés correctement,  elle  est à son deuxième   prêt   individuel.  
Ce prêt servira à acheter une importante quantité d’articles divers à Lomé (capitale du Togo). Elle effectue ses ventes à domicile et en ambulant dans les différents quartiers de la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant ou à crédit.  
Avec l’augmentation  de son chiffre d’affaire, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Aged 47, married and mother to 5 children, Mrs. Kassipin Traoré lives in a polygamous family with her co-wife, her husband and their children in the Hamdallaye quarter of the Koutiala prefecture, (Sikasso Region). Mrs. Kassipin did not have the chance to go to school much. She very quickly became interested in moneymaking activities that she learnt from her mother. After twenty years experience in the business, she is well known in her sector.

In order to keep her customers satisfied with quantity and quality, she did not waste any time in approaching the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After 4 solidarity loans (group loans) and one individual loan, all repaid correctly, she is on her second individual loan.

This loan will allow her to buy a large quantity of miscellaneous items in Lomé (the capital of Togo). She makes her sales door-to-door and in the street, and her customers are both male and female, paying by cash or on credit.

By increasing her turnover, she will make a monthly income of 75,000 FCFA which she will use to pay her income taxes, put towards the daily household expenses and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy miscellaneous items

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 55 years old and a married mother of six children. Currently, two of her children are in school while the others work. Mary starting selling smoked fish two years ago at a community market where she lives. She buys her stock of fish from Mankessim in the central region of Ghana. She then prepares and serves her customers with good quality, tasty fish and, because of this, many customers buy from her stand. Mary sometimes sells through hawking when market conditions are slow. She has a good customer base with customers traveling from surrounding communities to buy her fish.

Mary is requesting a loan to upgrade her stock of fish. She dreams of giving her two children a high quality education with the proceeds from her business. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fish and dried fish

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Né vers 1967 à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso), Monsieur Adama O. est  un polygame qui est mari de deux  épouses et père de 4 enfants. Il  vit chez lui-même dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de  Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Du à des problèmes de famille, il a  prématurément abandonné les études pour s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente d’essence. Il a appris cette activité  auprès de son grand frère.  Aujourd’hui cette activité lui procure assez de revenus et  sa notoriété est grande au niveau de la ville de Koutiala. 
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle et l’agrandissement  de son activité,  monsieur  Adama a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, il est à son premier  prêt  individuel.  
Ce prêt lui permettra d’avoir sur soi, un important stock d’essence. Il s’approvisionne à Koury auprès des grossistes dans la  préfecture de Koutiala et effectue sa vente d’essence en détail,  dans son petit étalage à Lafiala  à une clientèle constituée  de femmes et hommes, généralement  au comptant.  
Avec l’agrandissement de son activité, monsieur compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, prendre en charge les besoins de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité. 
IL envisage rembourser ce prêt correctement pour qu’il puisse bénéficier un autre dans le but d’élargir davantage  son activité.
texts.en:
Born around 1967 in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkino Faso), Mr. Adama O. is a polygamist who is husband to two wives and father to 4 children. He lives in his own home in the Hamdallaye quarter of the Koutiala prefecture (Sikasso Region). Due to family problems he gave up his studies prematurely to start earning money, notably by selling fuel. He learnt this business from his grandfather. Today this business provides him with sufficient income and he is well known in the town of Koutiala.

In the interest of customer satisfaction and in order to grow his business, Mr. Adama approached the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for what is his first individual loan.

This loan will allow him to have a large stock of petrol himself. He buys from wholesalers in Koury in the Koutiala prefecture and then sells the fuel piecemeal from his small stall in Lafiala to both male and female customers, generally for cash. By growing his business, he will bring in a monthly income of 90,000 FCFA which he will use to pay his income taxes, take care of his family and invest the remainder in his business. He plans to pay back this loan correctly so that he can have another, with the aim of expanding his business.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fuel (UK: petrol, US: gas)

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia is 40 years old and married with two children, both of whom are in school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother whose hard work helps to support her family. For the past three years, Afia has supported her husband in providing for the household by selling used shoes and ladies' slippers. There is a very big market in Ghana for used shoes as brand new ones are very expensive for the poor. Therefore selling used shoes and slippers has created a market for many women like Afia.

With her loan, Afia wants to increase her inventory. She believes the loan will help her save for her children’s education, and also enable her to rent a store to minimize her frequent hawking.

loans.use: To buy more used shoes

loans.name: Agnes

texts.fr:
