This is Jacinta’s sixth loan with MFP, she knows she has to pay her installments on time and she promises to do so. She is well loved and respected in her communal bank since she always keeps the meetings running smoothly. She will buy more products to increase her stock with the 1500 soles she is asking for.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Justa

texts.es:
Justa, D. 55 años, es una madre que a lo largo D. su vida siempre trabajo mucho por salir adelante. Vive en su casa propia junto a sus 2 hijos: Reyna D. 23 y Cesar D. 18 y lo que más desea es tener una mejor calidad D. vida.

Junto a su triciclo sale todos los días a vender frutas al mercado Las Mercedes (mercado importante D. la ciudad D. Juliaca), las frutas las compra D. los carros que llegan D. la ciudad D. Puerto Maldonado y tiene muy buen ojo para escogerlas. Ella tiene muchos clientes, ya que es una vendedora muy carismática y alegre.
Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas D. venta, lleva 32 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día bajo el sofocante sol, lo cual hace que se canse más rápido. 
Para el futuro, espera juntar el dinero necesario para comprar un puesto dentro del mercado, para vender sus frutas con mayor tranquilidad.

Este es el sexto préstamo D. Justa con MFP, está dispuesta a pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, aunque para eso tenga que ahorrar poco a poco las ganancias D. sus ventas. En su banco comunal es una socia muy responsable. Con los mil quinientos soles solicitados comprará más frutas para poder incrementar la cantidad D. mercadería que venD..
texts.en:
Justa is 55 years old and is a mother who throughout her life has worked hard to get ahead. She lives in her house with her two children: 23 year old Reyna and 18 year old Cesar. What she wants the most is to have a better quality of life. With her cart, she goes out everyday to sell fruit in Las Mercedes Market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). She buys the fruit from the cars that arrive from Puerto Maldonado and has a very good eye for picking them. She has many customers, as she is a very charismatic and cheerful salesperson. What she likes the most about her work is talking with her neighbors in the market. She has been in this business for 32 years and she considers the most the most difficult thing to be to have to stay all day beneath the suffocating sun, which makes her tire quickly. For the future, she hopes to gather the necessary money to buy a place insiD. the market, so she can sell her fruit with more tranquility. This is Justa’s sixth loan with MFP. She is prepared to make her payments punctually, although for that she’ll have to save the earnings from her sales little by little. She is a very responsible member of her community bank. With the $525 (1500 PEN) requested, she will buy more fruit so that she can increase the quantity of merchandise that she sells.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in merchandise

loans.name: Zulma

texts.es:
Zulma, de 24 años, es una joven muy alegre y carismática, vive en la casa de sus padres, a quienes desea ayudar en los gastos del hogar.

Su negocio es la venta de utensilios para cocina y comedor, de forma ambulatoria recorre las ferias de la ciudad de Juliaca en busca de clientes que necesiten de sus productos, ella es una joven muy empeñosa y no se rinde fácilmente, ya que siente que es hora de apoyar a sus padres con los gastos familiares.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que tiene libertad para decidir sus horarios de venta, lo cual es muy importante para ella, ya que también tiene que cumplir con sus estudios. Lleva 2 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es tener que caminar todo el día en busca de clientes. 
Para más adelante, espera juntar el dinero necesario para alquilar una tienda y poder vender sus utensilios con más tranquilidad.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Zulma con MFP y está dispuesta a pagarlo a tiempo, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a las socias de su banco comunal donde es muy querida por el resto de sus compañeras. Con los mil soles solicitados comprará más utensilios para implementar mejor el stock de su negocio.
texts.en:
Zulma, 24 years old, is a very cheerful and charismatic young woman who lives in the home of her parents and would like to help with the household costs. She is in the business of selling kitchen and table utensils. She travels around the markets of the city of Juliaca searching for clients that need her products. Zulma is a very hard-working young woman who doesn't give up easily, as she feels that now is the time to support her parents with the family costs. What she likes most about her work is that she has the freedom to choose her own hours, which is very important to her as she also has to complete her studies. She has been in this business for two years and for her the hardest part is having to walk all day to find customers. In the future, Zulma hopes to save enough money to rent a store in order to sell more utensils more comfortably. This is Zulma's second loan with MFP and she is prepared to pay on time, as she doesn't want to cause problems for the members of her communal bank, where she is dear to her other companions. WIth the 1000 soles from this loan, Zulma will buy more utensils to better stock her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen, de 22 años, es una joven muy alegre, vive en una habitación que le cedieron sus padres y lo que más desea es trabajar muy duro para salir adelante.

Su negocio está ubicado en el mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), ella se dedica a la venta de casacas, las cuales trae desde la ciudad de Desaguadero (provincia de Puno, fronteriza al país de Bolivia), ya que ahí encuentra modelos más novedosos para ofrecer a sus clientes.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta, lleva 3 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar las casacas hasta la ciudad de Juliaca, ya que los fardos son muy grandes y pesados. 
Con el tiempo, espera tener una tienda más grande de casacas, donde pueda brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

Este es el primer préstamo de Carmen con MFP, es consciente que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente y está dispuesta hacerlo. En su banco comunal es una socia muy solidaria. Con los mil soles solicitados comprará más casacas para implementar mejor su puesto de venta.
texts.en:
22-year old Carmen is a lively young woman who lives in a house that was left to her by her parents. Her biggest wish is to work very hard so that she can get ahead in life. Her business is located in the San José market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). She sells jackets which she brings in from Desaguadero (in the province of Puno, close to the border with Bolivia) as the styles there are more up-to-date. Chatting with neighbouring stall owners at the market is the part of her job that she most enjoys. She’s been doing this work for three years. The hardest part is transporting the jackets to Juliaca as the bundles are large and heavy. Eventually she hopes to have a bigger store so that she can offer better service to her customers. This is Carmen’s first loan with Kiva partner MFP. She is aware that she has to pay back all loan instalments punctually and has made arrangements to do this. She is a supportive member of her community bank. With the 1000 sole loan, she plans to buy more jackets with which to stock her market stall.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy more stock

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn C. is 44 years old and happily married to Felix C., who is 50 years old. Her husband works as a screen printer. Although he works hard to support the family, they never end up with enough money to meet their daily expenses and other expenses, like educational expenses. So Evelyn thought of a way to help her husband, and this was the start of her frozen foods business. They are blessed with three children: Kevin Ray, 17 years old; Kenneth Jim, 14 years old, and Karl Brian, 12 years old. All of their children are now in school so educational expenses are high. 

Evelyn got her capital for starting a business from a loan she received from Kiva's field partner, Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), when she became a member. Now she has been in her business for four years, and her business continues to grow, because she makes good use of every loan she receives from ASHI. She will be using her seventh loan to buy different frozen foods to sell so that her business will continue to improve.

Just like every parent dreams for their children, Evelyn also dreams of her children finishing their studies until college. That is why she and her husband are working hard to prepare for their future. She knows that with the financial support she is confident ASHI will give them, her dreams for her children will be possible.

loans.use: To finance selling of frozen foods

loans.name: Normita

texts.en:
Normita N. is the mother of two children: Diana Faye, 11 years old and Radge Norman, 7 years old. She is 34 years old and married to 38-year-old Edgar N.. Both their children are in primary school, so their current educational expenses are not too high. Nevertheless, Normita wants to work hard because she knows that in the next five years they will be spending more money on education, and she wants to save for their future needs. Her husband works abroad as an electrician. He suffers from being away from his family just to give them a better life. Normita found a way to help her husband provide for their family – this is her farming business. She is the one who personally manages it, sometimes hiring a laborer.

Since Normita became a member of Kiva's field partner, Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), she has used every loan as additional capital for her farming business. She will again be using this loan to buy necessary things for her business. She will buy rice seed, fertilizer and many other items, and she will use the loan to pay for all the activities in planting the rice. She is sure her business will be more productive with the help of this loan.

Normita's dream is to make her farm grow. Aside from the extra income it provides for their daily expenses and the education of their children, it is important to them because they inherited it from her parents. That is why she takes care of it.

loans.use: Additional capital for a farming business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita N. is from the village of Dimalco in Bonifacio Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Rosita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily-use products, soft drinks, and dry goods in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rosita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Rosita's fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ma. Aileen

texts.en: Ma. Aileen S. is a mother who dreams of helping her four children graduate from college. Her children are now from eight to 16 years old. Also, she hopes to have their dilapidated house repaired into a better dwelling. Simply, Ma. Aileen is wishing for nothing more than her children to live a life that is basically well and enjoyable. To make her dream come true, she has requested a loan through ASHI for the capital to start a business selling fish and vegetables. Her new business will supplement her husband’s income and her children’s needs will be met, especially for education.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and fish to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita P. is from the village of Aloran in Misamis Occidental. She is 64 years old. Teresita is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Teresita raises and sells pigs. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be Teresita's ninth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her borrower's business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana P. will use the loan she is requesting to to start her own hog-raising business. She will use the profits from her business to supplement her husband's income as a laborer and to sustain the education of her four children, ages two to eight years old.  After her hog-raising business grows, she wishes to repair their dilapidated house to comfort her children. With her continuous access to loans through ASHI, Diana believes that some day she will realize her dreams for her children through the success of her business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and materials needed to build a pig pen.

loans.name: Marily

texts.en:
Marily B., 35 years old, is requesting for a loan to start a business selling fish. Despite her poverty, she has not stopped thinking of ways to achieve her dreams for her family, especially for her children. Instead giving in to her fears about life being poor, she has decided to play her productive role as a woman to be able to send all of her four children to college until graduation. Her children are now  whose age ranges from six to 12 years old.
For all of her years as a member of ASHI, she wishes to get more after repaying the others, so she can sustain the growth of her business and make more profits. By then, she hopes to purchase a lot where they can build a house of their own.

loans.use: To buy a larg volume of  fish to sell

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en: Carmen M. is the loving wife of a farmer named Eddie. She responsively nurtures her four children whose ages range from 11 to 19 years old. Despite the poverty and adversities she faces every day, Carmen and her family hold onto each other and to the vision of her four children graduating from college. However, with only her husband’s income from being farm laborer, her dream would not be possible, because the income is small and insufficient. Her husband's income pays only for food for her family and small things they need. With the loan she is requesting now, Carmen wants to start a business preparing, buying and selling food. She will use the proceeds to support her children’s education and for improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food preparation business

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana M. is from the village of P-4 Villaflor in Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old. Juana is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Juana owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store where she sells daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Juana has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Juana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Juana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Juana's sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz D. is a typical mother who wishes nothing more in life but for her children to finish college and to get the family out of poverty. Together with her loving and supportive partner in life, she works hard to earn money for the everyday expenses of her family. However, her business is still too small to earn enough for their daily financial needs. 

Therefore, Luz is requesting for a loan through ASHI for capital to expand her business. She is very eager for this vision because, without her business, she and her husband could have no other means to earn as much as possible. While her two children (now ages 7 and 10) are young, Luz wants to invest more money through loan so it reaches sustainability.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for preparing and selling food

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
A 43-year-old mother named Salvacion Baño is requesting a loan through ASHI, now that she has been recognized as official member. The amount she requests will be her starting capital for a buy-and-sell business. 

Salvacion will use the proceeds of ther business to achieve her dream of sending her four children to college until they graduate. Three of them now are in high school and one is in pre-school.  Salvacion’s husband is a laborer, so his income is not enough to finance her children’s education in college. Their dreams would be impossible to achieve because the income is just small and sporadic. The loans that are available would give her and her family great opportunity to bring themselves out of poverty.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar and assorted vegetables to sell

loans.name: Exequiel

texts.en:
Due to our economic crisis, Exequiel J. ,Jr. and his wife Analie J. of Brgy. DMP Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya are working very hard to earn a living and to pay for the schooling of their four children. The two eldest are now in tertiary education while the two youngest are in secondary education. In this regard, they need to earn more income so that they are able to support their children's studies.

Exequiel is a 'jeepney' driver while his wife is engaged in running a general store, selling different snacks and groceries. Every week, they are able to earn an average net income of P 1,500 which they utilize to acquire their daily basic needs and pay the tuition fees and allowances of their children. In this regard, they need to earn a higher income so that they can maintain their businesses and they are able to meet their daily needs.

Because of this, Exequiel applied for a loan amounting to P 5,000 to be used for the maintenance of his 'jeepney' and for improvement to his wife's business. They believe that they will be able to improve their living conditions with the support of KIVA lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for the maintenance of their businesses

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario N. is 46 years old, and her partner now is Eugenio Garcia, 58 years old, with whom she has found true happiness. They were blessed with one child, Mark Lester, 12 years old. From her former unsuccessful marriage, she has two children, Rose Anne, 20 years old, and Rogelyn, 16 years old, for whom she is still responsible.

One source of their income comes from the salary of Eugenio, working as a foreman carpenter. The three children are currently studying so creating more expenses, especially her two older children who are in college. Rosario helps Eugenio in providing for their family through the income from buying and selling various frozen foods. Sometimes she sells some beauty products, and also offers her customers pedicures or manicures, treatment for their hair, a spa for their feet, and facial treatments.

Her 7th loan from Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) is will be used in buying what is needed for these businesses: frozen foods and beauty products and for her other business, nail polish, things used in treating hair, face, and feet. She is sure after buying all this, she will get a big boost in income because these are all the things that help her in improving her businesses.

The education of her children is her priority in life, so she will do everything to make her businesses grow. One dream of hers is to have a beauty salon where they live so she can always afford the educational expenses of her children.

loans.use: To finance all her businesses

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: This is Lolita A., 51 years old. She and her husband Ernesto, 49, are vendors. They live in Parola, Tondo, Manila, a shanty community very near Manila Bay. They have seven children; one is in college and two are in high school. Lolita has been doing business for fifteen years already. She buys and sells assorted fruits and vegetables. They have a stall in Gabis Munting Palengke (a mini-market) in Kalentong. They also have a stall in a flea market near their residence. Lolita hires two assistants. She earns P 90,000.00 a month from both stalls. Her profits go to their family’s basic needs and for their children’s education. She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2003. Lolita currently applied for a new loan in the amount of P 50,000.00. With this fresh additional capital, she can purchase more assorted fruits and vegetables for her business. She hopes to send all her children to school from the fruits of her labor. It has been her dream as well to own a service vehicle for her business. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Adelaida S. is a 35 year old businesswoman from a Habitat for Humanity village in Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. Her husband Domingo, 39, is a jeepney driver. All their three children are in grade school. Adelaida has been into direct selling of cosmetics and apparel for three years now. She makes more than P 3,000.00 a month from this business. Just three months ago she opened a general store in her house. Over time, her general store steadily grew and now earns P 6,000.00 a month on top of her earnings from her cosmetics. Her profits are helpful enough to support her children’s education. She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for two years since 2005. She recently applied for a P 10,000.00 loan with CCT as additional capital for her store. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for general store

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en: Pacita C., who is 54 years old, and her family are among the poor families who were awarded a government-subsidized house in a Habitat for Humanity village in Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. She lives with her husband and four children. Pacita is into the buying and selling of mobile phones, portable DVD players, and other gadgets in her community. She started to engage herself in this business three years ago. She earns more than P 10,000.00 net income a month. While she enjoys her business, she sometimes gets fed up with customers who don’t pay on time. She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. Her loans provided by the cooperative were very helpful in the growth of her business. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of P 17,000.00 as additional capital for her business. Pacita wishes to soon establish her own stall where she can sell her items. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Noraida

texts.en: Noraida T. is a 62 year old transport service operator living in a Habitat for Humanity village in Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. She lives with her husband and three adult children. Noraida owns and manages a fleet of motorized tricycles. She has three units of tricycles plying the Baseco-Delpan-Divisoria route. She has been in this business for three years now. She employs two drivers. She earns a total of close to P 12,000.00 every month. From her profits, she was able to improve their house. She has just finished paying off her latest loan from CCT. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of P 12,000.00 so she can have enough funds for the mechanical maintenance of her fleet. She will also purchase spare tires and other parts. Noraida is looking forward to buying her 4th tricycle unit soon. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Mechanical maintenance of tricycle fleet

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en: Harriet B.  is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 38 years old and divorced with 4 children to take care of aged 2 to `5 years. She also takes care of other orphans. Harriet is such a hard working lady having been a housewife before her husband walked away. She has a Kiosk in Namuyenje that she has been running for 2 years and earns a small  profit that helps her manage her family. She sells all kinds of products ranging from muffins to fresh vegetables to earn a living. Her dream is to expand her business further as well as to continue educating her children. Harriet needs a loan to help restock her business with more goods to increase her profits.

loans.use: Restocking her kiosk with more goods.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy G., 30 years old, grows vegetables and sells different kinds of fruits and vegetables in her village. She is married to Nelson G., also 30 years old, who works as a farmer in their village. Judy and Nelson are gifted with one child named Jonel. 

Judy plants vegetables in her fields and backyard for both subsistence and business. Judy also buys fruits and vegetables in different villages that have vegetable farms. She buys it wholesale and then sells it to different vendors in public markets. Her business needs major capital because when she goes to different villages, she rents a car to purchase vegetables and go to the market.

She is requesting Php 5,000 for additional capital to buy more kinds of fruits and vegetables to sell. She wants to maintain her business as her main source of income. She is giving her full time and effort in her fruits and vegetable farming and vending business because she believes that God will make a way to make her become successful.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and fruits to sell

loans.name: Aboubakar

texts.en:
Aboubakar H. is 27 years old, single, and he takes care of one dependent who is 7 years old. Aboubakar lives in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Aboubakar is a true entrepreneur and has been operating his business successfully since 2004. He owns a house where he has sewn different models of clothes since 2004. His business is open from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day and he employs two people in his business. 

Aboubakar is now requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing more sewing machines as well as creating more jobs for more people, which will help him to increase the profit. Then, through that profit, he will be able to save for the future.

loans.use: To buy more sewing machines and equipment

loans.name: Railway Quarters A 1 Omara Mary Wilobo Group

texts.en:
O. Mary W., 50 years old, is the chairperson of her loan group. She is widowed and blessed with two school-aged children. She also looks after two dependents where by one is an orphan. 

For 13 years, she has been operating a restaurant. She is requesting a loan to purchase different food types for the restaurant. She wants to add capital into her business so that she can expand it. She is a hard working business woman who is struggling very hard to earn a living. Her future dream is to have enough capital to shift her business from restaurant to buying produces such as bags of beans, maize, millet, dry cassava, rice, etc.

loans.use: To purchase different food types for restaurant

loans.name: Railway Quarters A1 Ceazaria Ayugi Group

texts.en:
C. Ayugi is the treasurer of her loan group. She is a 43-year old business woman, married with nine children of which two are schooling. For 6 years, she has had a business selling produce such as maize, rice, and beans, among other things.

She is requesting a loan to purchase to increase her stock of beans, maize, dried cassava, and rice in her business. She is active and enthusiastic business woman whose hope is to see a growth in her business and, in her dream, obtain her own store.

loans.use: To increase the stock of beans, maize, dried cassava and rice for business

loans.name: John Bosco

texts.en:
John Bosco is 31 years old and is married with two children aged 3 and 10.

Jean Bosco has been in the business of secretariat services for five years. His business is open from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. and he works hard to service his clients in the community. This is reflected in the fact that his monthly profit before this loan was approximately 150,000 RWF per month (approximately US$270) and now his monthly profit has been highly increased.

Jean Bosco is requesting his 2nd loan to purchase new equipment and it is worth noting that he repaid his first loan on time and in full. His hope is that by building this business and making it bigger, he is securing a promising future for his young family. He thanks VFC and Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment

loans.name: Railway Quarter A 1 Anyango Polina Group

texts.en: 30-year old A. Polina is the representative of her loan group. She is married with seven children, five of whom are in school. She also looks after four orphans and her mother too. For 10 years, she has owned a business selling produce. She is using the loan to increase her stock of produce, such as rice, beans, maize, peas, simsim, etc. She is hoping to improve her business so that she can pay school fees for her children. She is a stress free and happy lady whose dream is to work very hard and educate her children.

loans.use: To increase produce stock

loans.name: C8670 Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Y. Uwamahoro is 30 years old and married with three children aged 4 through 10. She and her family live in Rubavu District in Gisenyi Province, about 3 hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Y. really knows her business very well - she has thirteen years of experience in the banana industry. She employs several people from her community and is known for quality products and good service. Her business yields a monthly profit of 50,000 RWF (approximately US$90) and she hopes this loan will help her to increase this amount.

Y. is requesting this loan from Vision Finance Company to provide needed working capital, to purchase inventory and to manage the cash flow of her seasonal business. She has had two previous loans from Vision Finance Company which she repaid on time and in full. Y. thanks VFC and Kiva for supporting her enterprise.

In the photo we do not see seven people because F. Mukarwego was not available.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Senior Quarters 1 Adoline Akao Group

texts.en: 45 year old Adoline A. is married with 10 children, seven of whom are in school. She also takes care of three dependents, two of whom are also in school. She works in the retail business that she has been running for over seven years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items, especially essentials like soap, salt, sugar, etc. At least now she is able to provide basic needs for her family. She wants to work very hard and obtain enough money to support herself financially and materially to become independent from borrowing. She wants to remain proud of her kiva loan that changed her lifestyle positively.

loans.use: To purchase retail items for her business

loans.name: Valens

texts.en:
M. Valens is 32 years old, single, and he is the president of a group called Dukore, that has been in business since 2006. They have a small shop selling a variety of goods such as foodstuffs and some drinks. This business is open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

This group is requesting their first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to expand their business as well as to get enough profit, which, in turn will help them to buy their own houses and save for their future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of foodstuffs and drinks for sale

loans.name: Senior Quarters 1 Acen Suzan Group

texts.en: Suzan A., a 39-year-old business lady, is a married mother of five children, all attending school, and also looks after two other dependents. She has operated a retail shop for the past five years, and is requesting a loan to purchase essentials including soap, sugar, salt, match boxes, and cooking oil in order to expand the business. Suzan is a hardworking lady whose dream is to obtain a piece of land in the town of Lira and construct a commercial house.

loans.use: To purchase for her business soap, sugar, salt, match boxes, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Kodzo

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de friperie. Son commerce se situe dans le quartier de Nukafu à Lomé, à côté d’une station d’essence. Il a débuté cette activité depuis 2005 et grâce à cette revente, il arrive à subvenir à ses besoins. Il vend des chemises, des pantalons Jeans à des prix défiant toute concurrence. Il a de bonnes relations avec ses fournisseurs, qui lui fournissent les meilleures marchandises à l’ouverture de nouvelles balles. Il sollicite en ce moment un crédit de WAGES pour commander une balle de T-shirt, une balle de pantalon Jean et une balle de chemise. Cet homme n’est pas marié et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
This young man works at selling used clothing to earn a living. His business is situated in the Nukafa district of Lomé, next to a gas station. He began the business in 2005 and, thanks to reselling these used clothing, he manages to support himself. He sells shirts and Jeans at prices which can't be outdone. He has good relations with his suppliers, who furnish him the best merchandise when they open up new bales. He is presently requesting a loan from WAGES to order a bale of T-shirts, a bale of Jeans, and a bale of shirts. This gentleman is not married and is not responsible for any children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 3 bales of used clothing: T-shirts, Jeans, and shirts

loans.name: Kudzo Anani

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme est un étudiant en cours de formation. Pour supporter financièrement ses études, il a décidé en 2003 de se lancer dans la vente de friperie dans le quartier de Tokoin Wuiti à Lomé. Sa clientèle est essentiellement constituée d’étudiants qui viennent faire des achats chez lui. Les jours où il va suivre ses cours, il confie son commerce à un jeune homme. Il vend des chemises, des pantalons Jean et même des tissus pour pantalon. Il a approché WAGES pour faire un prêt lui permettant d’acheter 02 bals de chemises, 02 bals de Pantalon Jean et 20 mètres de tissus pour pantalons. Il est célibataire et sans enfant.
texts.en:
This young man is a student who is taking training. To support his studies financially, he decided in 2003 to embark on selling second-hand clothing in the Tokoin Wuiti district in Lomé. His customers are essentially composed of students who come to him to make their purchases. On class days, he entrusts his business to a young man. He sells shirts, jeans, and even fabrics for pants. He approached WAGES to take out a loan enabling him to buy two bales of shirts, two bales of jeans, and 20 meters of cloth for pants. He is unmarried and has no children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 bales of shirts and jeans and a few meter of fabrics for pants

loans.name: Senior Quarters 1 Jeniffer Ogwang Group

texts.en: Jeniffer O., the President of this group, is 38 years old, married, and blessed with three children, all attending school, and looks after six dependents who are also in school. Jennifer sells produce including maize, simsim, and beans, a business she has now operated for over three years.  Unfortunately, increasing prices and seasonal changes have really reduced her business profits, so she is requesting a loan to purchase at least 20 bags each of maize, simsim, and beans in order to bolster profits.  Jennifer is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to support and look after neglected children and orphans.

loans.use: To purchase additional produce (maize, simsim, beans, etc) for her business.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Managing a general store is what Adelaida C. does for work. She is 47 years old, and she is married to Ferdinand C.. They have been blessed with three children: Benjie, who is 21 years old and a high-school graduate; Dave, who is 20 years old and a high-school graduate; and Maribel, who is 19 years old and an undergraduate in college.

Adelaida would like to purchase more merchandise for her store, but she does not have enough capital; that’s the reason why she is asking for additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 PHP. She is hoping that her request will be granted. She is lucky because her husband is in full support of her business. They work hard to improve their way of living. Adelaida hopes that her business will become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en:
Olive T. is 30 years old and is married with three children aged 6, 9 and 12. Olive and her family live in Musanze district in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

In 2008, Olive opened a restaurant and employs three people in her business. Her restaurant is open every day from 6 in morning to 10 in evening.

Olive is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to have sufficient working capital to purchase modern equipment for her restaurant. With this loan she hopes to increase her business, which will help her to serve more customers.

loans.use: To purchase modern equipment

loans.name: C2577 Abizeranye Group

texts.en:
Pelagie K. is 31 years old, married with 2 children aged 2 and 8, and she also takes care of 1 dependent. Pelagie lives at Musha where she is the president of a group called ABIZERANYE and where they operate businesses selling a variety of goods.

Pelagie’s group is requesting their first loan from Vision Finance Company. This loan will allow them to purchase more inventory for sale in their shops to attract more customers and make more profits. Once their businesses are successful, they hope to create many other jobs as well as creating many sources of incomes.

loans.use: A variety of goods for sale such as sugar, salt,  rice, cooking oil, etc

loans.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo is a 50 year old married woman with nine children, who are between 13 and 25 years old. Five of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a seven room house, in which she is staying with twelve people. The family doesn’t have access to electricity or running water. Teo also takes care of additional family members. 

Teo has a stall selling vegetables, bananas and firewood. She pays for transport costs to and from Kalerwe Market. On average she receives approximately 20 customers a day. She has been in this business for thirty years and with MCDT seven years. She is currently servicing her thirteenth loan with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, accommodation and medication. Her business challenges include transportation and the rainy season, which prevents her customers from coming to her. Teo wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of tomatoes, cabbages, sacks of bananas and firewood. She wants to see her business grow and start buying directly from farmers.

loans.use: purchasing boxes of tomatoes, cabbages, sacks of bananas and firewood

loans.name: Méminétou

texts.fr: Cette femme n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, elle s’est lancée en 2003 dans la vente d’une bouillie préparée à base de mil, très appréciée de la population. Elle exerce ce commerce dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé. Elle vend les matins et les après-midis. Les soirs surtout, elle dispose tellement de clients que la plupart ne disposent pas de place pour s’assoir. Elle voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour pouvoir renouveler son stock de matières ; ce prêt lui permettra donc d’acheter 05 sacs de mil, 04 sacs de sucre, du bois de chauffage et d’autres éléments indispensables.
texts.en:
This woman is not married and has no children to support. To support herself, she embarked on selling millet porridge in 2003. People appreciate millet porridge a lot. She operates this business in the Agoè district in Lomé. She sells in the mornings and afternoons. In the evenings in particular, she has so many customers that most of them lack a place to sit. She would like to obtain a WAGES loan to be able to renew her stock of ingredients. This loan will enable her to buy five sacks of millet, four sacks of sugar, some firewood, and other indispensable items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of millet, sugar, firewood, and various products

loans.name: Tchilabalo

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a appris le métier de soudure ; en 2002, il a ouvert son atelier de soudure dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans l’éducation scolaire de son enfant. Il s’est spécialisé dans la fabrication et vente de portes métalliques, parfois sur commandes. Il emploi des apprentis soudeurs qui l’aident dans ses activités. Beaucoup de clients apprécient sa franchise dans le respect de son calendrier de livraison. Il a besoin urgemment d’acheter des éléments entrant dans la fabrication de portes métalliques ; c’est pour cette raison qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 tôles d’une épaisseur de 1,5 ; 10 tubes carrés de 30 ; ainsi que d’autres outils indispensables. Cet homme n’est pas marié.
texts.en:
This gentleman has learned the trade of welding. In 2002, he opened his own workshop in the Agoè district in Lomé. This business enables him to do his financially part in providing education for his child. He became specialized in making and selling metal doors and gates, sometimes by special order. He employs apprentice welders, who help him in his work. Many customers appreciate his frankness with respect to his delivery calendar. He has an urgent need to purchase essential items for making metal doors; this is why he’s requesting a WAGES loan for buying five sheets of metal of 1.5 thickness; ten square ‘30’ tubes; as well as other supplies and equipment. He is an unmarried man.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheet metal, square tubing,and iron plates

loans.name: C2579 Dukore Group

texts.en:
M. Valens is 32 years old, single, and he is the president of group called DUKORE. He has been in business since 2006 with a small shop selling a variety of goods such foodstuffs and some drinks. This business is open from 6 AM to 8 PM every day. 

This group is requesting their first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to expand their businesses as well as make more profit, which, in turn will help them to buy their own houses and save for the future.

loans.use: A variety of foodstuffs and some drinks

loans.name: Starch Factory B1 Middy Ojok Group

texts.en:
Middy O. is the president of her group. She is a forty-six year old married woman blessed with eleven children, five of whom are going to school. She has three other dependents as well. 

She is engaged in the charcoal business, which she has been doing for a period of five years. She will use the loan to purchase at least fifteen bags of charcoal; this may enable her to make reasonable profits.

With the loan, she believes, her children will be able to study because they will be going back to school. At least now they are eating food at least twice a day, whereas previously it was hard for her to manage feeding the family even a single meal. Middy is a hardworking business woman. She promises to work very hard and obtain some money so that she can fulfill her dreams.

loans.use: purchasing at least fifteen bags of charcoal

loans.name: Domingo

texts.en:
Domingo P. Sr., or “Boy” as he is known in his village, is 58 years old. He only finished elementary education. Due to hardships, he was unable to pursue his studies. Instead, he helped his father cultivate their farm lot by planting rice and some vegetables. When he was 18, his uncle, who is a mechanic, hired him to be a conductor and collector in his jeepney. At the same time, he taught him how to drive and how to repair the jeepney; after a year, he could perform both tasks with ease.

Following this, Domingo decided that he wanted to purchase his own jeepney so that he could apply what he had learned from his uncle. From that time onwards, he tried to save more of his income; after three years, he bought his own jeepney, which he used to earn income. 

Domingo is married to Teresita P.; they are gifted with five children. They want their children to finish their studies so that they will find stable jobs someday. Consequently, they are doing their best to earn money with which they can support the studies of their children. His wife is engaged in selling snacks in the school campus. 

As a result of their patience and sacrifices, they are able to earn an income of P 8,000 per month, which they use to meet their daily needs and finance the schooling of their children. Due to the high cost of commodities and school expenditures, however, they need to earn more income to meet their needs. Domingo thus wants to borrow P 5,000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of his jeepney. He believes that with this financial assistance he will be able to use his jeepney regularly to earn income for the needs of his family.

loans.use: maintaining his vehicle

loans.name: Bassarou

texts.fr: Cet homme a appris la menuiserie ; en 2003, il a ouvert son atelier de menuiserie dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé. Il est marié et a à sa charge un enfant. Cette activité lui permet de subvenir aux besoins financiers de sa famille. Il dispose de nombreux clients fidèles qui apprécient énormément la qualité de ses travaux. Il fabrique des lits et armoires à la mode en ce moment. Il a besoin de s’approvisionner en planches et aussi certains outils neufs ; c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 01 défonseur, 10 planches double, un appareil de menuiserie dénommé Moelle 6 circulaire ainsi que d’autres outils nécessaires.
texts.en:
This is a man who learned the trade of furniture-making. In 2003, he opened his own workshop in the Agoè district in Lomé. He is married and has a child to support. This business of his enables him to provide financially for his family. He has a number of loyal customers who greatly appreciate the quality of his work. He makes beds and armoires that are in style at the moment. He needs to stock up on lumber and also on some brand-new tools; this is why he’s requesting a WAGES loan for purchasing a router, ten double boards, and a piece of carpentry equipment called Moelle 6 circulaire, as well as some other necessary tools.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy carpentry tools

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 46 years old. She is married; she and her husband have one child. Her husband is an engineer in a private firm. She sells sarongs, jewelry and umbrellas. She has been in this business since 2004. She is an energetic woman and she hopes to attract more customers to her stall during and after the high season. She is requesting for a loan amount of N 80,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Rafig

texts.en: Rafig was born in 1964, and he is married with two children.  He lives in the Fuzuli region. Rafig has run a furniture sales business for five years. Now he is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy more furniture to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy more furniture

loans.name: Sabouratou

texts.fr: Cette dame s’est spécialisée dans la vente de matériaux de construction. Elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2001 dans le quartier d’Avédjie à Lomé ; elle connaît parfaitement son secteur d’activité, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à la plupart de ses besoins. Elle a loué un local dans lequel elle stocke ses marchandises. Elle a tissé de bonnes relations avec beaucoup de chefs chantiers qui viennent s’approvisionner chez lui. Pour disposer de nouveaux stocks, elle sollicite en ce moment un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 04 WC ainsi que plusieurs autres articles essentiels. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
This lady specializes in the sale of construction materials. She began this business in 2001 in the Avédjie area of Lomé; she has mastered this field of business perfectly, which allows her to meet the majority of her needs. She has rented a place in which she stocks her merchandise. She has developed good relations with many construction site managers who come to her to obtain their supplies. To establish new stocks of merchandise, she is currently seeking a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 4 toilet fixtures as well as several other essential items. She is unmarried and has no children in her care.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy toilet fixtures and various other items for resale

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
N. Florence is a friendly, hardworking and determined lady. She is 25 years old and the leader of her lending group in Mukono. Florence is married with a four-year-old child and she also takes care of some orphans.

Florence is a businesswoman involved in the sale of fish from Kiganda, and she is able to make a weekly profit of 50,000 UGX. This is a new business she started four months ago, and she is successful due to her cleanliness and friendly nature at work. Florence dreams of expanding her business and getting a much bigger place, as well as buying her own plot of land. She needs a loan to buy more dry fish for resale since this will bring in more income.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Endurance

texts.en: Endurance is 35 years old and married with five children. She sells utensils, such as cooking pots, plates and spoons, to make a living in her community in Warri, Delta State. She is determined, through her business, to lift her family above poverty. She is requesting a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more utensils to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more utensils to sell

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange Utamuliza is 26 years old, married with two children aged five and three, and she lives in Musanze District, the northern province of Rwanda, approximately 3 hours' drive from the capital city, Kigali. Her village called Rwaza, is where she has had her business selling various kinds of products like rice, sugar, salt, cooking oil, cosmetic products, etc., for seven years.

Although Solange has been in business since 2002, her profit is too low to expand meaningfully and she believes that a small amount of additional capital would change that for her. For that reason, Solange is requesting her fourth loan from Vision Finance Company to purchase more merchandise which will make her more efficient and effective and thus more successful. She thanks VFC and Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Awawou

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et est mère de 02 enfants. Elle s’est spécialisée dans la vente de denrées alimentaires dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Elle vend des épices pour la cuisine, de l’huile blanche et bien d’autres ingrédients indispensables. En ce moment elle a besoin de renouveler son stock presque épuisé ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 bidons d'huile, 04 sacs d’arachide, 01 sac d’épices et divers ingrédients. Elle a une ferme assurance de rembourser son prêt dans les délais qui lui seront exigés.
texts.en:
This woman is married and has two children. She specializes in the sale of foodstuffs in the Agoè district in Lomé. This business allows her to contribute financially to the management of her household. She sells spices to be used in food, white oil, and many other essential ingredients. At the moment, she needs to replenish her almost-depleted stock; this is why she is seeking a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 5 cans of oil, 4 bags of peanuts, 1 bag of spices, and other ingredients. She is very confident that she will repay her loan within the given deadline.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell foodstuffs

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel is the kind and devoted father of two children. He is a farmer and also operates a tricycle passenger service in his village of San Pedro, Roxas, Isabela. As the breadwinner for his family, he does his best to maintain good family relationships. He does not want his family to feel hungry and that is why he pushes himself to work hard and double his time. His dreams are for his family to have good health and a good future.

Noel is very concerned about his children’s education. He wants them to finish their education and have a successful future. Noel's wife takes care of their children and manages the family's wellbeing. As a father, Noel worries about his family's future. His tricycle does not provide a good quality ride all the time. Therefore Noel is kindly requesting the amount of 6,000 PHP from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of his tricycle to make it more comfortable to ride.

loans.use: To repair and maintain his tricycle

loans.name: Vasif

texts.en: Vasif was born in 1968 and he is married with two children. He lives in the Fuzuli region. Four years ago, Vasif started a cattle-breeding business. Now he is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy five calves to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy five calves

loans.name: Omaléyé E.

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu des accessoires traditionnels pour la cuisine; elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2006 dans le quartier d’Agoè Camp FIR. Cette vendeuse ambulante exerce cette activité qui lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Elle vend des paniers, des balais artisanaux, des spatules pour préparer la pâte de maïs, des éventails. Elle est connue de beaucoup de clients qui font des commandes chez elle. En ce moment elle voudrait disposer d’un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 15 paniers, 05 balais, 20 spatules et 15 éventails. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
This lady runs an income-generating business selling traditional food preparation accessories; she began this business in 2006 in the Agoè Camp FIR district. This traveling saleswoman's business allows her to contribute financially to the management of her household. She sells baskets, handmade brooms, spatulas for preparing maize paste, and fans. She is known by many of her clients, who give her their orders at home. At the moment, she would like to obtain a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 15 baskets, 5 brooms, 20 spatulas, and 15 fans. She is married and has 3 children.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy baskets, brooms, spatulas, and fans

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo F. is 26 years old and married to Marichu F., who is now working abroad. The couple is blessed with one child, Darius, who is four years old. Bernardo and Marichu are helping one another to provide for the needs of their family. Bernardo hopes to improve his family's standard of living, and he believes that through “sacrifices and patience” he will be able to achieve success in life.

Bernardo would like to have additional capital for the general maintenance of his motorcycle and for his other businesses, such as farming and hog-raising in his backyard. He is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 PHP.

loans.use: As additional capital for his motorcycle business

loans.name: Afiwoa

texts.fr: Cette femme habite le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé où elle a ouvert en 2004 une boutique de vente de boissons alcoolisées et des produits de beauté. Cette activité lui permet d’assurer financièrement l’éducation scolaire de ses 03 enfants. Sa boutique est bien connue de nombreux clients qui apprécient le bon accueil qu’elle développe à leur endroit. C’est pour renouveler son stock qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 cartons de boissons Castel, des mèches, des crèmes de beauté et divers produits cosmétiques. Cette dame n’est pas mariée.
texts.en:
This woman lives in the Agoè district of Lomé, where she opened a store in 2004 selling alcoholic beverages and beauty products. This business allows her to provide financially for the education of her three children. Her store is well-known by many customers who appreciate the hearty welcome and atmosphere she has developed. It is to replenish her stock that she is seeking a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 20 cartons of Castel drinks, hair extensions, beauty creams, and various other cosmetics. This lady is unmarried.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy alcoholic beverages, hair extensions, and body creams

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: Cette femme est une revendeuse de poissons fumés dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé ; elle achète des poissons tout frais auprès des pécheurs de la plage de Lomé et les revend ensuite sous forme de poissons fumés. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Ainsi, ces poissons sont fumés par des procédés traditionnels avec surtout des cartons vides servant de bois de chauffage. Beaucoup de ménages s’approvisionnent chez elle en laissant des commandes de vente. Elle a approché WAGES en ce moment pour acheter 06 cartons de poissons frais, 30 cartons vides qui serviront de bois de chauffage et divers autres produits. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman is a retailer of smoked fish in the Agoè district of Lomé; she buys fresh fish from the fishermen at the beach in Lomé and resells them in smoked form. This business allows her to contribute financially to the management of her household. These fish are smoked using traditional methods, especially with empty boxes serving as firewood. Many households obtain their supplies from her by leaving their orders with her. Currently, she has approached WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 6 boxes of fresh fish, 30 empty boxes to serve as firewood, and various other products. She is married and has two children.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fresh fish and empty boxes

loans.name: Starch Factory B1 Collin Okao Group

texts.en:
C. Okao is the representative of her group. She is 23 years old, married and has one school-aged child. She also has four dependents in school, too.

For the past three years Okao has had a business purchasing Mukwano cooking oil and selling it at retail prices. She is using her loan to purchase at least three 20 liter jeri cans of Mukwano cooking oil to retail to her customers. The loan is helping her by adding capital to her business. Okao is an active businesswoman whose dream is to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To purchase Mukwano cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Mrs. Evangeline G. is from the village of Sibutad, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 43 years old. She is married and blessed with 4 school-aged children. She owns and operates a business venture selling beauty products from AVON Cosmetics. She is just starting this business.

In 2009, she joined PMPC to access their programs and services. Currently, she's requesting her 1st loan in the amount of 3,000 P which will be used for purchasing beauty products from AVON Cosmetics.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for purchasing beauty products from AVON

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah is 32 years old and married with six children between the ages of 3 and 17. All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. Hadjah owns a three-room house where she lives with eight people. The family doesn’t have access to electricity or piped water.

Hadjah has a stall where she sells bananas. She pays for transportation costs to and from shopping in Mbarara. On average, she receives thirty customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala.

She has been in this business for six years and with MCDT for seven years, servicing her twentieth loan and working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, accommodation and medication. Her business challenges include transportation and the rainy season, which makes movement of vehicles impossible. Hadjah wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She wants to see her business grow bigger so she can start selling at wholesale prices only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha C. is 55 years old and happily married to Yulo C., who is 59. Most of her children now have their own families. One child that is still living with them is Raquel, who is 25 years old and has received only a low level of education. That is one of their frustrations, not being able to send their children to college. That’s why Editha is trying her best, with the help of her husband, so that their grandchildren will never lack a college education.

Their main source of income is through their fishing business that is personally managed by Yulo, because he is a fisherman. Editha also runs a business, the direct-selling of items from Avon Company and from other companies that sell different personal products. Since she joined the Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), Editha has always used the loans that she received for their fishing business, to make it grow more. Now, her eighth loan will be used again for this business. Editha will buy necessary things like different fishnets, materials used for making a fish pond and many more. She is sure that after buying all of this their business will be more productive.

Editha's biggest dream is to make their business continue to grow and increase their income so that she can help with the education of their grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy fishnets and materials for a fish pond, etc.

loans.name: Alaskar

texts.en:
Alaskar was born in 1973. He lives in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has two children. Four years ago he started this business. He plays a drum at weddings. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business.

Alaskar also plays other musical instruments. He would like to buy a synthesizer to improving his business.  Since now he only plays a drum at weddings, a synthesizer other smaller musical instuments increase his product offerings for weddings which, he hopes, shall increase his income.

"I can play not only drum, but I don't have good income enough to purchase other musical instruments for improving my business."

"The people will invite me to weddings not only to play on my drum, but I will play the synthesizer other instruments also, and I will be in more demand and get better income."

loans.use: to improve his business

loans.name: Loty

texts.en:
Loty O. is now 47 years old and married to Joey O., who is 48 years old. In the long years of their marriage they were given five children: Judy Ann, 27; Bill Joel, 25; Jackielou, 24; Joelito, 20, and Alexis Miel, 4 years old. Most of their children are currently studying, so more money is being spent on the expenses for their education. Loty and Joey have doubled their work in order to earn more income for them.

One good thing is that some of their children are now working, so they are contributing to the educational expenses of their siblings. Aside from the employment of their other children, their main source of income is through their fishing business. Loty's husband is a fisherman, and she is the one who personally manages the business. Loty helps her husband through the financial aspect of their business. The money that finances the business comes from Loty, which she gets from the Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), since she become a member. She has always properly utilized every loan that she received. Generally, she used the loans to buy the needs of their business to make it more productive. She will do the same thing with this loan, to make sure that the business will grow. One dream that Loty and Joey share is to have a big fish pond in the sea that would provide them with income and enable them to live a better life.

loans.use: To buy things necessary for their fishing business

loans.name: Jocye

texts.en:
Joyce is 30 years old and married with three children between the ages of 2 and 11 years. All her children go to school. Joyce takes care of additional family members. She rents a three-room house where she lives with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water.

Joyce has a salon where she sells hair extensions and cosmetics. She pays for transportation costs to and from her work. On average, she receives 30 customers a day. She works in Kampala city.

Joyce has been in this business for six years and with the Kiva field partner, MCDT, for nine years, now servicing her twentieth loan and working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, accommodation and medication. Her business challenges include the increasing prices of cosmetics and defaulters.

She wants to use this loan to buy more hair extensions and boxes of cosmetics. She wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more hair extensions and boxes of cosmetics

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda P. is 6 years older than her husband, Marticiano P., at the age of 55 years old. Most of their children now have their own families, so their family started to get big. Rosenda wants to help all her children in raising their children, especially financially; that is why Rosenda and her husband are striving hard to provide for their big family. The main source of their income is through their fishing business that is personally managed by her husband because he is a fisherman, but aside from that they also run a fish and gasoline business. All of this business contributes to their daily income, but the fishing business is the one that contributes the most, so they focus on it.

Since she became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), every loan that Rosenda receives is used in improving this business; that is why her business will continue to run and grow. Her fourth loan will be used again in buying necessary things needed by her business like fishnets, accessories for the fishnets, and much more. And some part of the loan will be used in buying what is needed for their secondary business, which is the buy and sell. She is hoping that after buying all of these things their business will improve more.

Rosenda's dream is that someday they will own a boat and fish cage. Now they will work hard to make this dream possible. And after this dream becomes a reality of course the result will be that their income will increase and they will help their children in providing for their children; and they will be able to release their family from the shadow of poverty.

loans.use: To finance their fishing business

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 44 years old, and she is married with 7 children. She sells rubber shoes, umbrellas, and utensils like cooking pots in her stall. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to be a major distributor of utensils in her community in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more utensils to sell. She hopes to attract more customers to her stall. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more utensils to sell

loans.name: Starch Factory B1 Mirriam Owor Group

texts.en: Mirriam O. is 24 years old and married with 2 children, one of whom is in school, and she also has 1 dependent. She has dealt with tailoring services so far for 3 years and provides sewing services. She does not have enough capital, whereby she cannot purchase material for making dresses and other designs for sale. She is requesting the loan to purchase material. She hopes her business is going to be boosted because she is targeting the Christmas season. Mirriam is a business lady whose dream is to educate her children, and she wishes to raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase material for making different designs for sale

loans.name: Anar

texts.en: Anar was born in 1989.  He lives in Fuzuli region.  He is married and has one child.  Three years ago, he started a cattle breeding business. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy 4 calves to expand his cattle breeding business.

loans.use: to buy 4 calves

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric K. is 19 years old and single; he lives in Gasabo district where he owns a shop selling a variety of goods, as his photo indicates. His business is open from 5 AM to 8 PM every day.

Since Eric has only one year's experience in business, his profit is still too low to expand meaningfully but he believes that a small amount of additional capital would positively change his life. For that reason, Eric is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders to purchase a variety of goods for sale which will make him more efficient, effective, and thus more successful.

loans.use: Additional goods for sale such as sugar,  rice, flour, etc.

loans.name: Myferlene

texts.en:
Myferlene B. and Jonathan B., both the same age, are happily married to each other. They are thankful to have a child named Nathan James now 4 years old. According to the happy couple, while Nathan James is still young and not yet going to school, they will start saving for his future needs. While their expenses are not that great, they will start to save. Their main source of income is from their farming business that is personally managed by Jonathan because he is a farmer. This business has been up and running for 5 years now, and they want this business to continue to grow so that they will be able to save for the future of Nathan James.

Every loan that Myferlene received through Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) after becoming a member has been used in improving this business. Her 4th loan will be used as additional capital for their farming business. Now, they plan to plant pineapples instead of rice, and they will buy all the necessary things needed for planting this, such as pineapple seedlings, fertilizer and many more, plus the expenses for the work that will be done to plant the pineapple. Myferlene is hoping that with the use of the loan, she’ll be able to make their business more productive.

Myferlene is working hard with the help of her husband so that their business will grow and the result will be they can give their child a better future. She really wants to release their family from the shadow of poverty and that is why she is striving so to succeed.

loans.use: For additional capital for their farming business

loans.name: Proscovia

texts.en:
Proscovia is 31 years old, married with two children aged 6 and 9 years. Both her children go to school. Proscovia owns a three-roomed house where she lives with four people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Proscovia takes care of additional family members.

She owns a stall selling second-hand clothes and uses public transport to and from shopping. Proscovia sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. Proscovia has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her sixteenth loan, working with the same group-mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and rent and school fees.

She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Zahir

texts.en: Zahir has been in the food sales business for 3 years. He was born in 1988, is single, and lives in the Fuzuli region. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: to buy foodstuufs to sell

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 42 years old and married with 6 children. She is a tailor and she also sells curtains and carpets. She is a hard-working woman and she is very diligent in her business. The demand for her goods is high, and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes for a loan amounting to N70,000 to purchase more curtains and carpets to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more carpets and curtains to sell

loans.name: Appolinarie

texts.en:
Appolinarie M. is 26 years old and married with two young children aged 3 and 8. She lives in Musanze district in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Appolinarie has been an entrepreneur for many years and has ten years of experience selling a variety products like sugar, rice, beans, salt, cooking oil, etc. She employs one person in her retail shop.

This loan will allow Appolinarie to purchase more merchandise to sell in her shop to attract more customers and, hopefully, to make more profits. Appolinarie currently hopes to make a monthly profit of 25,000 Rwf (approximately US$45).

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Ovoke

texts.en: Ovoke is 30 years old. She is married; she and her husband have four children. Her husband works as a security guard in a private company in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. Ovoke sells hair extensions and plaits beautiful hair styles for her customers. She is requesting for a loan amount of 60,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions to sell. This is the high season for the sales of hair extensions and she hopes to make more profits during and after the season. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Vumirya

texts.en:
Vumiriya is 35 years old, married and has four children between the ages of 6 and 12. All of them are currently in school. She owns a three-room house where she lives with 10 other people because she is caring for several family members. The house has access to electricity and piped-in water. 

Vumiriya makes a living selling beverages in both wholesale and retail markets, and works hard to keep her costs low and operate as efficiently as possible. She has been a member of MCDT for five years and is applying for her 10th loan. She will use the money from this loan to pay rent for her shop, buy more supplies and cover the cost of her children's education. Her goal is to expand her business to the point where she is able to sell wholesale only.

loans.use: To pay various bills and buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Dancilla
