loans.name: Elsi Marina

texts.es: Elsi Marina Q. V., reside en el municipio de Armenia del departamento de Sonsonate. Elsi tiene 24 años de edad, es una mujer soltera vive solamente con su padres. Para Elsi es muy difícil ver que a pesar que su padre ya es una persona mayor tenga la necesidad de trabajar tan fuerte en la agricultura día a día, estas y muchas razones son la que le dan fuerzas a Elsi de manejar su propio negocio y así poder ayudar económicamente a su familia, hace cinco años inicio con su negocio de platillos típicos y bebidas, donde le ha ido muy bien y es por eso que solicita de un crédito para aumentar la producción de sus platillos.
texts.en:
Elsi Marina Q. V. lives in the town of Armenia, department of Sonsonate. She is 24 years old, single, and lives with her parents. Elsi finds it very difficult watching her elderly father continue to work so hard every day as a farmer because of financial necessity. For this reason, she started her own business five years ago so that she could help with the family expenses. Elsi prepares and sells traditional dishes and beverages. Her business is doing very well, so she is requesting a loan so that she can increase her production.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her inventory of supplies for her business

loans.name: Starch Factory B1 Ann Atoo Group

texts.en: Ann A. is the president of her group. She is widowed with seven children, four of whom are going to school; additionally, she has three other dependents. She has been in the bakery business for over twenty years now. She has been struggling to find enough capital to keep the business running. She is consequently requesting this loan, which will add capital to her business and allow her to, for example, purchase bagiya ingredients such as cassava flour, sugar, cooking oil, et cetera. The loan will seriously encourage her to work very hard, educate her children, and open up a boutique selling clothes in order to generate even more income.

loans.use: adding capital to her business

loans.name: Farhad Gardashali

texts.en: Farhad has been in the house repairing business for 7 years. He lives in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has 2 children. He currently needs a loan of 2,000 AZN, which he will use to purchase things that will improve his business.

loans.use: purchasing things that will improve his business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane S. is a resident of Marcos, Roxas, Isabela. She is 39 years old and operates her business retailing goods in her general store. She has already two years in her business and it is still growing.

Mary Jane is married to a kind and patient, loving husband named Eddie S.. They are gifted with four children and two are taking their studies. One is taking his college level of education and the youngest is presently in elementary school. Jane wants her two children to finish their education because she believes that education is the only wealth that she can give them. 

Mary Jane and her husband will do their best to provide for their children’s needs but even their source of income is really not enough. They will do their best to improve their business to provide greater income for the family.

Mary Jane is asking to borrow PHP 5,000 to improve her business to earn a higher income for her family. She wants to have more stock to be able to gain more profit.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to improve her business

loans.name: Starch Factory B 3 Sandra Atine Group

texts.en:
Sandra A. is a businesswoman, twenty-nine years old, who is married with four children, all going to school. She has dealt in tailoring services for over four years.

Sandra is using the loan to purchase clothes for sale and to purchase clothing material for making beautiful designs for sale. She wants to improve her stock of materials for a big profit return.

Sandra is a hardworking business lady whose dream is obtain a wholesale shop selling clothing material and other clothes.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell and material for making beautiful designs

loans.name: Emeteria

texts.en: Emeteria A. is from the village of Tonggo, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Emeteria owns and operates a business selling vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eighteen years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Emeteria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Emeteria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma A. is 30 years of age and is from the village of Santiago, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. Her husband, Bell A., is 31 years old.

Gemma delivered her baby just last month but it did not survive. She said that life is full of problems but she just takes it as a challenge. At present, she is busy managing her “talipapa” or small market where she sells vegetables, meat, fish and barbeque in the afternoons.

Gemma’s husband is busy with their farm activities but also helps Gemma in selling their meats and vegetables. Sometimes, Gemma sells her food and snacks around their village by going house to house. She is almost one year in her business.

Gemma wants to borrow Php 6,000 as additional capital for the improvement of her business. She wants to have more items to sell to be able to increase her income.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to have more items to sell

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en: Kiden J. is currently in the business of selling cakes and groundnut phaste (peanuts ground into a paste) and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts to sell. Kiden is 30 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Starch Factory B 3 Akite Rose Group

texts.en:
A. Rose is representative of the group. She is a business lady, twenty-seven years old, who is single with three children schooling and three dependents.

Rose has run a business selling wine since 2000. She is requesting the loan to purchase ingredients, such as pineapples, sugar, yeast, passion fruits, oranges, water, etc., for making wine. The loan is going to increase her capital.

Rose is a creative and hardworking business lady whose dream is to open up her own farm or factory for wine making.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients for making wine

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 57 years old, married, and blessed with six children. The family lives in the peaceful village of San Roque, Enrile, Cagayan.

William is a hardworking person who operates his repair shop business in their community. He has been in this business for more than ten years and earns a monthly income of PHP 4,000.

William wants his business to grow and, with this in mind, he is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 from Kiva lenders. This amount will be used to purchase tools needed in his repair shop. He believes that this will really help his business and help his family to have a progressive living.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed in his repair shop

loans.name: Starch Factory B2 Dorcus Okidi Group

texts.en:
Dorcus O. is a hardworking business lady, twenty-four years old, and married with four children, three of whom are going to school. She also takes care of two dependents who are schooling.

Dorcus deals in produce such as maize, beans, rice, etc., and has been in her business so far for five years. She is using the loan to increase her capital, pay fees, etc., and it will encourage her to work.

Dorcus is a very hardworking and encouraging business lady whose dreams are to purchase a plot of land, obtain livestock and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase produce such as maize, beans, rice, etc., and to pay fees

loans.name: Arvin Ian

texts.en: Arvin Ian S. is from the city of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City. He is 22 years old and is single. Arvin Ian owns and operates a business providing motor services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Arvin Ian joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his first from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Gune

texts.en: Gune M. is currently in the business of selling soda and water and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of soda to sell. Gune is 28 years old and is married to a peasant. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar at the nearby market. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of soda to sell

loans.name: Vinar

texts.en:
Vinar is 30 years old and is married to Amado. They are blessed with three children: Ruth Ann - 9 years old; Mary Ann - 4 years old and Aldrin - 3 years old. Her husband, Amado, is now working abroad while Vinar is managing their farm.

Vinar hires a driver to operate their passenger tricycle business in their village. Through her small businesses, she is able to help her husband in providing for the needs of her family. She works hard to achieve her dreams for her family.

Vinar wants her children to finish their education and have a successful future. For this reason, she would like to borrow additional business capital of PHP 7,000 from Kiva lenders. This will be used for the repair and maintenance of her tricycle so that her passengers will be safe.

loans.use: To pay for the repair and maintenance of her tricycle

loans.name: Starch Factory B 2 Scovia Adyek Group

texts.en:
Scovia A. is twenty-three years old and is married with three children, all going to school. She also has three dependents of whom two are going to school.

Scovia runs a business selling secondhand clothes and has been doing this business for over eight years. She is using the loan to improve her business - that is, to purchase used clothes for sale. This will enable her pay her children’s school fees and also to raise her standard of living.

Scovia is a really courageous business lady whose hope is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Koligo

texts.en: Koligo J. is currently in the business of selling both fresh and dried fish and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of onions to sell. Koligo is 35 years old and is married to a fisherman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of onions to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is 36 years old and blessed with one child. She makes a living selling fruits and vegetables at the main market in Eldoret town. She joined KADET after learning about it from friends. She has applied for this loan in order to buy more items to sell, including bananas various kinds of vegetables. Her dreams is to succeed at her work, buy some land and build a house.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and fruit to sell to her customers

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco T. lives in the town of P-6 Gata Daku Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is 52 years old, married and has four grown children. Francisco makes a living by transporting people around on his motorcycle. He has been in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from his work.

In 2007, Francisco joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services that would help him improve his life and expand business. He has successfully repaid three previous loans from GDMPC, and is applying for a new loan to use to expand his business. He plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units overing the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand a small transportation business

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en: Ruth N. is a hard-working and very friendly woman who has made a living running a tailoring business in Kitega for the last 25 years. She is a married, has eight children and also cares for several orphans. Due to increased competition in her business, the number of customers Ruth serves has been falling, along with her profits. She believes she can turn this around with a loan to her group, pictured here. She will use her portion of this loan to buy more cloth and materials, thereby increasing the number of items she has to sell. Her goal is to earn enough money to allow her children to stay in school and go to college.

loans.use: To buy materials for a tailoring business.

loans.name: Erastus Makokha

texts.en:
Erastus E. is 35 years old, married and blessed with two children. He makes a living by farming and by transporting people and goods on his motorcycle. He was introduced to KADET by the chairperson of his current loan group, and is applying for this loan to repair his vehicle. Erastus has two goals: improve his transportation business, and grow enough crops on his farm to feed his family and have extra produce to sell.

About KADET:  
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. More information on KADET is available on this website: http://www.kadet.co.ke/

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Ricky

texts.en:
Ricky is 34 years old and lives in San Roque Enrile, Cagayan. He is married to Jackielyn, who is 32 years old and makes a living as a domestic helper in Hong Kong. They are blessed with two children: seven-year-old Arjay, who is in grade school, and five-year-old Ricalyn, who is in nursery school.

Ricky earns most of his income by providing transportation services, and supplements these earnings by raising hogs. He has applied for this loan to maintain his motorcycle and buy feed for his hogs. He thanks Kiva lenders for their support, because this help will allow him to expand his two small businesses and improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To maintain a motorcycle and to buy feed for his hogs

loans.name: Edlene

texts.en:
Edlene S. is from the village of Kingay Norte, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Edlene owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling products such as glasses,cellphone accessories watches, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Edlene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita Q. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 52 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Nenita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Luya

texts.en: Luya E. operates computer services such as typing and printing, photocopying, etc. She is requesting a loan to purchase one more computer to provide better services. Luya is married to an electrical engineer and has three children who all attend school. With the extra profits from the loan, she hopes to able to buy Internet devices such as a router (to connect computers in a network), Ethernet cables (to connect the computers to the router), RJ45 (plugs for cables), etc., and set up an Internet cafe. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase one more computer to provide better services

loans.name: Starch Factory B 2 Auma Janate Group

texts.en:
A. Janate is a hardworking businesswoman, thirty-seven years old. She is widowed, with no child of her own, but takes care of five dependents, all schooling.

For over seven years Janate has been dealing with produce: that is, selling rice, beans, maize, etc., but in small quantities. She is using the loan to purchase produce. For example she is buying one bag of maize, two bags of beans, one bag of rice, etc., and hoping to improve her business more.

Janate can now afford meals twice a day and she really wants to get to a better standard of living where she can continue to support her children, especially by paying their school fees.

Janate is a promising businesswoman whose dream is to construct a residential house.

loans.use: To purchase more produce to sell

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en:
Despite having a heart ailment, Aurea D., 48 years old and a widow, stays strong and courageous while facing challenges as a single parent to her daughter Kristine Joy. Her 14 year-old daughter is Aurea’s life and happiness. 

Imagining her dream of seeing her daughter graduate from college coming true through Aurea’s hard work and perseverance gives Aurea joy and contentment. 

To make her dream real, she is requesting a loan which will give her more opportunity to grow her business and enhance her profit. As the sole provider for her daughter Aurea has to make her business profitable and stable. Loans she can access through ASHI are her only hope in helping her and her daughter change their lives and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Most will be used to purchase cattle to fatten and sell and some will be used to buy sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Wilfrida Akoth

texts.en:
Wilfrida Akoth O. is 41 years old and a mother of four.

She has been operating a small retail shop for the last six years. This shop has enabled her to raise her standard of living and pay school fees for her children.

Wilfrida learned about KADET three years ago through a friend who is an existing KADET client. This will be Wilfrida’s fifth loan from KADET. She will use the loan to purchase more stock for her business. She also intends to start selling charcoal in an effort to expand her income base and diversify.

She harbors a long term dream of expanding her business into a wholesale store.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their families across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock for the shop.

loans.name: Lawrence Paul

texts.en:
Lawrence Paul N. is a married, 32 year-old man with three children. He does not own a shop; instead he is a mobile sales person and sells his secondhand clothing in several locations. He has been in business for seven years. He gets a profit of about 80000 KES per month.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend. He has never borrowed from another MFI and hopes to have a bigger shop to sell clothes in bulk. He has applied for a loan which he wants to use to buy more clothes and establish a permanent place in Kikuyu town.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their families across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more jackets and clothing to sell.

loans.name: Naome's Group

texts.en:
Naome K. is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. Along with taking care of and paying school fees for her 10 children, including siblings, she also looks after two of her late relatives' children.

Naome has a retail shop which she has maintained and expanded with the assistance of her first loan seven years ago.

She is requesting another loan so she can buy more products like bread, toothpaste, cooking oil and other products for her shop.

In the future Naome plans to become a wholesaler as well as build rental houses for increased income. By joining this lending group, she has benefited by being able to pay her children’s school fees on time plus owning more household items.

(The two ladies in the small photos appeared late for the photo hence taken each as an individual but a part of the group photo).

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Janice

texts.en:
Janice E. is requesting a loan through ASHI to be able to grow her cow and pig raising and selling business. For two years now this business has given Janice the opportunity to have her own income and to augment the income of her husband, a fisherman.

Janice spends her business proceeds for the education of her four children whose ages range from 3 to 13 years old.

Janice, 27 years old, knows how hard it is to live a life when a person is very poor. That is why loans she accesses through ASHI are used very well to finance her business so it becomes stable and she can help support the needs of her family, especially her children’s education until college.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet and cow for a livestock raising business.

loans.name: Zuleya Makongo

texts.en: Zuleya O. is a married woman, 26 years old, who is blessed with two children. She runs a retail shop selling things like soft drinks, cooking oil, snacks and other items at a place called Mautuna in Eldoret. Zuleya was introduced to KADET by an existing member. She has requested a loan which she is planning to use to buy more stock for her shop which includes cooking oil and sugar. Zuleya’s future dreams are to grow her business, to build a good house, and be able to educate her children. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy stock for her retail shop

loans.name: Neria

texts.en: Neria P. is from the town of Segatic Diot, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Neria owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store. She has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Neria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en:
In the photo, you can see Rashad who has a cheese production business. He has been in this business for four years.

Rashad was born in 1984, is single, and lives in Fuzuli region. Now he needs a loan of 1,700 AZN to improve his cheese production business.

loans.use: To improve his cheese production business

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita N.’s aspiration in life is nothing more than for herself and her husband to have healthy bodies. Clarita is 51 years old and her husband is three years older than her.

Their children have left and so Clarita and her husband have nothing to depend on in case of immediate financial need. Because of this, Clarita wishes that her pig-raising and fish-selling businesses will grow further and have larger profits. The loan she is requesting now will be the partial fulfillment of her wish. Therefore, she hopes that she will be given the loan through ASHI.

Though Clarita’s children have their own families now, she still wants to help them in their financial need so that her grandchildren are able to continue their studies until graduating from college.

loans.use: To buy a larger volume of various fish to sell and piglets to raise

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia M., 48 years old, is a proud mother of three children: Marjorie, 29; Maricel, 23; and Jay-ar, 21. She is proud of them because even though they’re not that rich and sometimes it’s hard to find money for their allowances, they still persevered to finish their studies. Now all of them are degree holders.

She and her husband Crispin M., 52 years old, are also proud of themselves because all of their hard work had good results. She knows that their children will have better lives but still not that easy, so they still need to work hard to continue to survive.

Their source of income comes from their variety store and their farming business. These businesses help them to make their dream possible, which is to finish the studies of their children.

Since Virginia became a member of ASHI she always used her loans to make their businesses grow and it really helps.

Virginia plans to use her 9th loan as additional capital for their farming business. This is because now their variety store has closed and they want first to focus on the farming business. She will help her husband to improve this business.

With the loan she will buy rice seeds, fertilizers, vitamins for the rice and other products to cultivate the land, plus she will pay expenses for labor. She is hoping that this will make their business more productive.

Because Virginia achieved her biggest dream -- to finish her childrens’ studies -- she just wishes now that God never tires of giving them blessings every day. Of course they will continue to strive hard so that their family will always experience a better life and also to extend their blessings to others.

loans.use: For additional capital for their farming business.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion Q. is from Valencia City. She is 40 years old, and married with 4 school-age children. To make a living, Concepcion owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of revenue comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Concepcion has owned her shop for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Concepcion joined HSPFI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion is requesting her first loan for 5000 PHP. She will use it to purchase additional products to sell. She will use the additional revenue to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note
To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Avellana

texts.en:
Avellana I. is 39 years old and happily married to Ernesto I. 49 years old. They have two children, Ara Lyn, 15, in fourth year high school and Jan Ernest, 5, in his pre-school year.

Ernesto works as a farmer and also takes care of the land in their place because the owner does not stay there so Ernesto is responsible for planting the land. This is one of their sources of income; also, Avellana manages a direct selling business of different ready-to-wear clothes, personal and beauty products. This is her one way of helping her husband provide for their family, because even though he works hard still the income is not enough. Also Avellana want to save for the future of their children.

Every loan that she has received from ASHI has been a big help in improving their business. She hopes to use her 7th loan for her business. She will buy items her business needs, like different pants, blouses, t-shirts, footwear, underwear, lotion, lipstick, cologne and so on. All of this is for sale and she is sure that after buying these she will get an income that will sustain the needs of their family.

Avellana’s dream is to make her business run and grow to the point that they can build their own store where customers can easily find her. When that happens she is sure that she can afford to send all of her children to school until college.

loans.use: For additional capital for her direct selling of different products.

loans.name: Faith's Group

texts.en:
Faith N. is the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is a friendly and hard working lady with a retail shop business in Sabwa that she has owned for 20 years.

Faith says that when she had just started there was very limited competition in her business, hence she made more money from many sales, but now due to a lot of competition her profits keep on deteriorating and this is why she takes loans.

She would like a loan to help increase her stock of goods in her shop so that it could become a one-stop shop for her customers. Perhaps in future she can turn it into wholesale. She would also like to build rental houses for future developments.

Faith is a married lady who takes care of 12 children aged 28 – 13 years, as she takes care of her siblings. She would like to ensure that she educates all of them. Her previous loans have helped her keep a steady supply of goods in her shop and to pay school fees for her children on time.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma. Luz R. wishes to have good health conditions to be able to serve her husband, her four children, aged from 6 to 19 years old, and her business customers.

Ma. Luz makes and sells nipa (palm tree leaf) shingles (one of the most common roofing materials used by people in the Province of Antique). She also has a manicure and pedicure business.

Her husband is a farmer and they both aim to send all of their children to college to experience a different kind of life – a life not being poor. Ma. Luz uses the proceeds from her businesses to augment her husband’s income and to support the needs of their children until they have reached their dreams.

With the loan she requests now, she hopes to grow her business and her profits. Without the loan, her dreams would be nothing and her children would still have the same kind of life in the future since Ma. Luz finds that ASHI is the only MFI that lends money with the interest she is capable of paying.

loans.use: Most will be used to buy and sell nipa shingles; some will be used to purchase materials for manicure and pedicure business.

loans.name: Mangal

texts.en: Mangal, son of M. M., lives in Jalalabad city. He lives with his family and has an energy drink shop. He has good experience in his business. He has been working at this trade since he was small boy. He opened an energy drink shop where he works independently, so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his stock and to make a good monthly income to support his family. He is happy that he can further his business in this way.

loans.use: He want to expand his inventory.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina Q. is from the village of Sinayawan, Valencia City. She is 59 years old. Angelina is married. To make a living, Angelina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Angelina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Angelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Angelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
A sad part of the life of the family of Lorena C. is that their head of the family has to work faraway so as to provide for them. Lorena's husband Junarlim C., 35 years old (one year older than her), works as an overseas Filipino worker (OFW) on the other side of the world. To provide for the needs of their children, now 10 and 5 years old, Junarlim decided to work overseas because people think that there are a lot of work opportunities there. Aside from the salary of her husband, one source of their income is Loren's sewing business. She decided to run this kind of business because she knows how to sew various clothes and also, she wants to help her husband in earning income for their family.

She joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) in 2003 and every loan that she received has been used in improving every business that she has. Now, her 9th loan will be used in improving her sewing business; she will buy necessary things for her business such as cloth, another sewing machine, thread, needles and many more, plus transportation fares. She is hoping that after buying all of these, her business will be more productive.

The dream of Lorena for their children is to have them finish their studies until college, so that the sacrifice of their father in working abroad will not be wasted and so that they will have a better life in the future. Lorena's dream for their family is also to make their house a bigger and stronger one. Her dream for her business is to continue to grow and in time they can buy their own van that can be used in delivering finished products.

loans.use: To finance her sewing business

loans.name: Karmen

texts.en:
Karmen is a young Palestinian women living in Bethlehem; she is married with two young children.

She has newly opened a grocery store to help her husband to have better income for the family. Her husband has an olive wood workshop; this workshop has been a family business for thirty years, and he inherited the skill and the workshop from his father). He makes a lot of souvenirs out of olive wood for tourists visiting Bethlehem, in addition to selling them to wholesalers who export these products to the USA and Europe.

Karmen has requested two thousand US dollars as a loan from FATEN for two things, first to enhance her newly opened grocery store, and also to buy olive wood for her husband's workshop.

Karmen appears in the picture at her shop.

loans.use: products for the grocery store and wood for her husband's workshop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M. is from the village of Mangidkid, Plaridel, Mis. Occ. She is 59 years old. Erlinda is married and has one child. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a "sari-sari" retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling dried goods in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Erlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additonal products to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine R. has been a member of ASHI since 2007. The loans she has accessed since then were the main source of capital for starting and sustaining a business. The proceeds of her hog fattening (pig raising) and her buying and selling of 'nipa' (palm leaf) shingles are her family’s main source of income. Her husband’s income being a farmer is still very small and sporadic and is used to supplement the basic needs of their three children, aged from six to 16 years old. All are studying and Josephine wishes them to continue their studies until graduating from college.

For now, Josephine is patiently waiting for her businesses to grow. She tries her best to maximize the profit she makes out of her businesses though it is still small. With loans she receives through ASHI, she believes that eventually her business will be successful and she will be able to bring her family out of poverty and that they will be able to have better living conditions.

loans.use: a large quantity of 'nipa' shingles to sell and  piglets for hog fattening

loans.name: Wengielou

texts.en:
A high school graduate, 19 years old and married, Wengielou T. is a retailer of goods in her general store at their village of Santiago, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is married to Reybell T., a farmer. They are gifted with one child named Anna Mae, five months old. As she dreams of getting an education, pursuing her college studies, and having a good future, Wengielou also dreams this for her child. She will try to do her best to fulfill these dreams for her child. During her time getting her education, she has lots of wishes.

Being a loving mother, Wengilou’s dreams now are for her child. She wants her child to finish her education and have a good future. Her business is the key to achieving it all. She will manage her business well and do her best to improve it. She wants to borrow the amount of Php 5,000 for additional capital to improve her store business.

loans.use: additional capital to improve her store

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
At the age of 65, Eliza P. is still fighting against poverty, the difference in her case is that she has now no partner in providing for her family; her husband left her and she is already a widow. A good thing is that her older daughter is now working as a nurse and the younger one is in her last year in college. Both of her children now have their own families so instead of them helping her, Eliza wants to help them in providing for her grandchildren.

So Eliza has never stopped working hard. As the source of their income, she runs a variety store business that serves as their main source of income and aside from that she is also a dealer in cloth, since most of her customers have sewing businesses. These businesses help them in their daily income and that is why now she always does the best thing to make these businesses continue to grow.

Now, accessing her 13th loan through Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) and a member since 1995, Eliza plans to use this loan in buying different things needed by her variety store business for its improvement. She will buy items like various groceries, soft drinks and many more. Also some part of the loan will be used for her other business. She is hoping that this whole thing will help her businesses to improve more.

Eliza is not dreaming for herself now, only for her grandchildren. She wants to help them in any aspect, in either financial or moral support. She always prays that her business will continue to grow so that she can help her children's families.

loans.use: To finance her variety store and also her  cloth business

loans.name: Nemenia

texts.en:
Nemenia D. is an active 50-year-old business woman who dreams of making her hog-fattening (pig-raising) and cattle-fattening (cow-raising) businesses grow and become sustainable to be able to support the needs of her five children whose ages range from 14 to 26 years old. Her husband Manolito is as hard-working as she. Aside from being a government employee, he does fishing for additional income during free time and on the weekend.

Nemenia had also been supporting her husband’s fishing business through loans she received from ASHI. Out of the proceeds she will be getting from her businesses, she would like to purchase a motorized fishing boat for her husband in the future.

Nemenia understands life though she finds it tough to fight against poverty sometimes. Her loving and supportive children and husband give her reason to think creatively of ways to overcome adversities in life so that her children will experience a different kind of lifestyle after they graduate from college.

loans.use: purchase piglets and feed and cattle for fattening

loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila is 40 years old and is from the village of District 2, San Manuel, Isabela. She wants to borrow PHP 15,000 to maintain her business. She works in retail, and grinds coconuts. Her business helps her provide for her children's education. 

Nila dreams that, through her business, she will be able to allow her children to complete their studies. Her business is also helping her to support her family's expenditures. Thanks to the help and support of her husband in managing their business, she has been doing this for fifteen years.

loans.use: additional capital for the maintenance of her business

loans.name: Junalyn

texts.en:
Junalyn Q. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 22 years old. Junalyn is married and has 1 infant. To make a living, Junalyn owns and runs a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling boiled duck eggs, locally known as balot, and penoy products to the community. Junalyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month.

In 2009, Junalyn joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Junalyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Junalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing additional products to sell

loans.name: Railway Quarter A 2 Rose Apio Group

texts.en:
Rose A. is her group's representative. She is thirty-four years old and married with five children, all of whom are in school. She also has three other dependents.

Rose runs a restaurant; she has done so for over three years. She will use this loan to purchase food (rice, bananas, meat, fish, chicken, vegetables, et cetera) and drinks (sodas, juice, water, et cetera) in order to meet different tastes. Since she is buying a greater variety of items to meet demand, more customers will be attracted to her restaurant. Eventually, she wants to expand her restaurant.

loans.use: purchasing food and drinks for her restaurant

loans.name: Jaimee

texts.en:
Jaimee C. manages a village store in the Barangay Mozzozzin Norte Sta. Maria Isabela. She is 30 years of age and married to Fedrick. They are blessed with three children: Maverick, age 7, Ferdick Jr., age 6, and Cedrick, age 2. The first two of her children are enrolled in a public school in their village. 

This business really helps improve their living conditions. For many years, Jaimee has tried to expand her business; unfortunately, she has usually failed because of her life's difficulties and a lack of financial capital. But she has not given up. Consequently, she wants to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. She knows that using the money wisely will lead to better business opportunities in the future.

loans.use: additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda J. is 46 years old. In 2004, a loan from ASHI provided her with enough capital to start up a business. Now, she is managing and financing three types of small businesses aside from her husband’s fishing business. Loans she acquired from ASHI have enabled her to have hog fattening (pig raising), rice farming, and rice selling businesses. Additionally, Merlinda also accepts laundry from the neighborhood. 

Overall profit, however, is still small. This is because everything her family, including her three children (who range from 12 to 20 years old), needs is taken from the income of her businesses and that of her husband’s. Nevertheless, Merlinda saves up some money to cover the expenses of her children's education.

Consequently, she has able to support her eldest child’s education in college until graduation. But now she has to support her two other children. In order to increase her savings, she is requesting this loan, which will be used to enhance her businesses until they grow and become more profitable. Merlinda enjoys working hard because of her children’s determination in their studies despite being poor, and her husband’s support.

loans.use: purchasing piglets and their food, and sacks of rice

loans.name: Railway Quarter A 2 Rajab Nusura Group

texts.en: Rajab N. is a hardworking businesswoman, and a widow with four children.  Two of her children attend school and she also supports the schooling of two orphans. She operates a restaurant and has been doing so for over seventeen years. She is requesting a loan to purchase additional supplies for her restaurant. She really wants to increase her daily profits. She is active and her dreams are to grow her business, educate her children, and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for her restaurant.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 27 years old and not yet married.  He has a grocery store in Hebron, a city in Palestine.  He is requesting a loan to increase his inventory of products in the grocery store - and therefore generate more sales and higher revenues - so he can provide his family with a better future.  He would like to say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To increase his inventory of grocery products.

loans.name: Geronima

texts.en: Geronima T. is a 55-year-old businesswoman. She and her husband Villardo share the responsibility of managing their businesses - a school and office supply store, a vulcanizing shop, and a sound system rental business.  These businesses provide employment for family members and also other people from the community.  Geronima says her earnings will be the main financial source for the education of her youngest child, who is now in high school, until college.  Also she helps to support the financial needs of her three older children, and is the provider of the family’s basic everyday needs. Her loan through ASHI is her main source of sustaining and growing her business.  Therefore she is requesting for a much larger amount now.  Geronima believes that the loan through ASHI will improve her family’s standard of living, and working with them will help improve her business management skills.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of school and office supplies in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Baryalay

texts.en:
Baryalay is an old man with lots of experience, though he is uneducated. He works in the sales and buying of rickshaws. He has been involved in this business for more than 12 years, but he would love to have more autos. To buy more autos, he needs extra money. Therefore, he requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani. 
He is a professional man and, from when he started this business, he has always wanted to improve his business. 

He is grateful for this loan process. He wants to say that it is his first loan and it is really great, especially for other small businessmen. He wants to continue his partnership and to encourage other workers to use this loan service.

loans.use: To buying more rickshaws for his buisness.

loans.name: Rona

texts.en: Rona A. is 20 years old and a new member of ASHI.  Her sweet and loving husband Marlon is a former technician and now drives a sidecar motorcycle, known as a tricycle, for hire.  Marlon’s income is the main financial source for the family.  Rona is a housewife and caring mother to her only child who is eight months old.  Aside from taking care of her child, Rona also wants to help contribute to the family income.  Therefore she is requesting a loan in order to buy spare parts to maintain the tricycle in running order.  As much as possible, Rona and Marlon want their passengers to enjoy good quality service.  Someday, Rona would like to purchase another tricycle for the hire business so they can generate more proceeds and improve the standard of living for their family, and to prepare herself financially for the future college education costs of her baby.

loans.use: To puchase spare parts for their hire tricycle.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis N. is 43 years old and the husband of Elizabeth Kabura.  They are blessed with four children.  Francis works as a tailor in Shanzu, Mombasa and has been in the business for 9 years.  He rents his workroom on a monthly basis.  Most of his clients are residents of the area where his shop is located.

Francis heard about KADET through an existing client and he is now requesting his first loan, in the amount of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).  He will use the loan to purchase materials like thread and fabric for his tailoring business.  In the future Francis hopes to establish his own shop instead of using the rented space. 

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to the economic empowerment of their clients across Kenya by providing financial services to improve living conditions for the micro-entrepreneurs and their children.  KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya.  You can obtain more information on KADET from their website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase materials like thread and fabric for his tailoring business.

loans.name: Senior Quarters 1 Ogoo Stella Group

texts.en: O. Stella is the leader of her group.  She is married with six children, and four of them already attend school.  She sells produce and green vegetables to customers on a small scale, by the kilo.  She buys one-half or one bag of maize, rice, or beans at a time.  She has been running this business for over five years now.  She is requesting a loan to purchase larger quantities of produce at a time, and to use as operating capital as she tries to improve her business.  She has finally achieved her goal of feeding her family.  Previously, they could afford to eat only a very little meal once per day, but now they are eating enough and at least twice a day.  She is also happy because her children are able to go to school. She is so encouraged because her dream is to educate her children and open her own store.

loans.use: To purchase produce in larger quantities.

loans.name: Eden Mae

texts.en:
Eden Mae J. is a 21-year-old mother who aspires to lift her family from poverty.  She joined ASHI in October 2009 because she believes it can help her achieve this dream, because ASHI strives for poverty eradication in the Philippines.  Eden felt in her heart that getting a loan through ASHI could change their lives for the better. Garry, Eden’s husband, supports his wife’s decision and believes in her mission for the family, especially for their two children who are ages 2 months old and 19 months old. 

The loan Eden requests through ASHI will be used to start a hog fattening (pig raising) business.  While Eden takes care of her two children at home, she can use her time productively by raising pigs in their backyard.  Once the pigs have grown, they will be sold live or slaughtered for pork retailing. Profits from this business will be saved for the future education of her children and to augment her husband’s income from being a laborer.

Although Eden is just starting with her business, she hopes to grow it to a piggery some day.  With her membership in ASHI and access to larger loans over time, as well as the support of her husband, she knows she will be able to achieve success in her business.

loans.use: To raise pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To register hs motorcycle taxi service

loans.name: Silas Anangwe

texts.en:
Silas is a 23-year-old married father blessed with two children.  His retail shop is located in the town of Panpaper.  He wants to improve his business prospects and decided to seek out a loan, so he visited a KADET branch and applied for a loan. This is his first loan with KADET and he plans to use it to add more stock of cooking oil, sugar, and rice to his shop.  Silas plans to become a distributor to other retail shops and one day dreams of becoming a landlord.  He views rental homes as a more stable income.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to the economic empowerment of their clients across Kenya by providing financial services to improve living conditions for the micro-entrepreneurs and their children. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. You can obtain more information on KADET from their website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more stock to his retail shop, such as cooking oil, sugar, and rice.

loans.name: Alfred Lumbasi

texts.en:
Alfred is a 30-year-old married father blessed with three children.  He runs a motorcycle transport business located in Mautuma, a part of Eldoret.

Alfred decided he wanted to expand his business opportunities and decided to seek out a loan with KADET.  He plans to use this loan to buy a pick-up truck for transportation and to expand his other business, which is in farming.  He hopes to improve his ability to meet his family's basic needs.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to the economic empowerment of their clients across Kenya by providing financial services to improve living conditions for the micro-entrepreneurs and their children. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. You can obtain more information on KADET from their website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a pick -up truck for business transportation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his grocery store and buy more and new products

loans.name: Phanice Naliaka

texts.en:
Phanice is 31 years old, married, and blessed with six children.  Her business is located at Nyoritis in Eldoret.  She sells cereals like maize to her customers.  Phanice was introduced to KADET by existing group members. With the loan she is receiving from KADET, she plans to buy more maize stock to use for cooking and serving to customers.  Most of her customers who come to eat her cooked maize are residents within Nyoritis.  Her future dreams are to buy a plot of land.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to the economic empowerment of their clients across Kenya by providing financial services to improve living conditions for the micro-entrepreneurs and their children. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. You can obtain more information on KADET from their website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more maize stock.

loans.name: James Luvuka

texts.en:
James is 34 years old, married and blessed with three children. His business is located at Lusweti in Eldoret.

He decided he wanted to improve his business and sought out a loan with KADET, a Kiva partner. James is planning to use the loan to buy more seedlings and also to buy fertilizer for his farming business. His dream is to improve his farm and better provide for his family.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.name: Ismael Kato

texts.en:
Ismael is 30 years old, married and blessed with two children. He runs a retail business which is located at Imbuga in Eldoret.

Wanting to improve his business and profit margins, Ismael sought out a loan with KADET, a Kiva partner. With the loan he is taking from KADET, he intends to buy stock to sell, including paraffin and super oil. His dream is to prosper and provide for his family.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.name: Airen Musimbi

texts.en:
Airen is 56 years old, married and blessed with three children. She sells clothing at Mbururu in Eldoret.

She was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by a neighbor. She is planning to use the loan she is taking from KADET to buy more stock of clothing for both adults and children. Her future dream is to buy a plot of land and construct rental houses.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke
