loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 45ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de DJININA, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent comme activités génératrices de revenus, le commerce de charbon de bois et d’articles divers il y’a un peu longtemps. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur onzième prêt et tous les dix prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 250 sacs de charbon de bois et une grande quantité d’articles divers tels que les habillements et les produits de premières nécessités. Les articles divers et charbon de bois sont achetés en détail dans les villages environnants et à Fana et sont revendus sur place à DJININA  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are married women who are, on average, 45 years old with 2 children. With their husbands and children, they live in large traditional households and reside in the village of Djinina, Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, in the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighbourhood and familial relations. They have been running income-generating businesses selling firewood and various items for a little while now. These women work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners) with the goal of making their lucrative businesses more durable. They are seeking their eleventh loan, and their previous ten loans were all repaid properly. With this loan, they intend to buy 250 bags of charcoal and a large quantity of various items such as clothing and basic need goods. These various items and charcoal are bought at retail in the neighbouring villages and in Fana and are resold on-the-spot in Djinina to a clientele composed of men and women. They each foresee realizing an average profit of 20,000 FCFA per month. A portion of these profits will be reinvested in their businesses and the rest will be used to meet their daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal and various other items

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth A. is from the village of Libertad, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old, is married, and is blessed with two school-aged children. Elizabeth owns and operates a business selling bananas in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns PHP 3,800 net monthly. In 2005, Elizabeth joined PMPC to access its programs and services. Currently, she's obtaining her 9th loan of PHP 12,000 which will be used as additional capital for her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her banana vending business

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkan sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 43ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de DJININA, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers tels le charbon de bois l’habillement etc. 
Ces femmes viennent d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, des sacs de charbon de bois et des habillements pour femmes et hommes de tous les âges. Les habillements sont achetés à Fana, le charbon de bois est acheté en détail dans les villages environnants et sont revendus sur place à DJININA  généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkan group are married women who are, on average, 43 years old with two children. With their husbands and children, they live in large traditional households and reside in the village of Djinina, Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, in the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighbourhood and familial relations. They run businesses selling various items such as charcoal, clothing, etc. These women joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of making their lucrative businesses more durable. They are working on their first loan through the institution. With this loan, they intend to buy bags of charcoal and clothing for men and women of all ages. The clothing is bought in Fana, the charcoal is bought at retail in the neighbouring villages, and the goods are sold on-the-spot in Djinina, generally in cash to a clientele composed of men and women. They each hope to realize an average profit of 25,000 FCFA per month. A portion of the profits will be reinvested in their businesses, and the rest used to meet the daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and charcoal

loans.name: Djantoyerela Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djantoyerela sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 51ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de DJININA, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers tels le charbon de bois, le bois de chauffe, des habillements etc. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur onzième prêt et tous les dix prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de charbon de bois. Les habillements et le charbon de bois sont achetés à Fana et dans les villages environnants pour être revendus sur place à DJININA à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  Elles comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Djantoyerela group are married women who are, on average, 51 years old with three children. With their husbands and children, they live in large traditional households and reside in the village of Djinina, Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, in the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighbourhood and familial relations. They run businesses selling various items such as charcoal, firewood, clothing, etc. These women work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of making their lucrative businesses more durable. They are working on their eleventh loan, and their previous ten loans were all repaid properly. With this loan, they intend to buy clothing for men and women and a large quantity of charcoal. The clothing and charcoal are bought in Fana and in the neighbouring villages and then sold on-the-spot in Djinina to a clientele composed of men and women. They each intend to realize an average profit of 25,000 FCFA per month. A portion of the profits will be reinvested in their businesses, and the rest used to meet the daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal and clothing

loans.name: Sarakognouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sarakognouma sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 46 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de DJININA, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés et exercent le commerce d’articles divers tels le lait, le bois de chauffe, le charbon de bois, les céréales etc. 
Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur onzième prêt et tous  les dix prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter,  400 sacs de charbon de bois et une grande quantité d’autres articles divers tels le lait et les céréales. Les céréales, le lait  et le charbon  de bois sont achetés en détail dans les environnants  du village et sont revendus au comptant ou à crédit sur place à DJININA et au poste de sortie de FANA à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment avoir chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Sarakognouma group are all married women who are, on average, 46 years old with 2 children. With their husbands and children, they live in large traditional households and reside in the village of Djinina, Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, in the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighbourhood and familial relations, and run businesses selling various items such as milk, firewood, charcoal, cereals, etc. These women joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of making their lucrative businesses more durable. They are working on their eleventh loan, and all ten of their previous loans were repaid properly. With this loan, they intend to buy 400 bags of charcoal and a large quantity of various other items such as milk and cereals. The cereals, milk, and charcoal are bought at retail in the neighbouring villages, and are resold in cash or on credit on-the-spot in Djinina and at the Fana exit station to a clientele composed of men and women. They each estimate earning an average profit of 20,000 FCFA per month. A portion of the profits will be reinvested in their businesses, and the rest used to pay for the daily household expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk, cereals, and charcoal

loans.name: Bembeya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bembeya est composé de quatre femmes (une veuve et  trois mariées) vivant dans de grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans,  4 enfants et habitent  dans le quartier Djaka (Kirango)  de Markala (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié et de voisinage et ont une activité génératrice de revenu portant essentiellement sur la vente du poisson sous toutes ses formes.
Dans le souci de mieux rentabiliser leurs activités, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Le groupe Bembeya est à son 5ème prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursé les quatre prêts précédents.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 16 paniers de poisson frais et 40 barres  de glace (fournies par les transporteurs venant de Bamako). Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger, qui est trié dont une  partie est séchée (soit sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos »). Le poisson se vend sous toutes ses formes : les poissons frais se vendent sur place au bord du fleuve Niger,  à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala parfois en ambulant dans les quartiers, le frais conservé dans de la glace se vend à Ségou (au marché château) et  Bamako,  le poisson séché dont une partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue et en l’hivernage où elles gagnent plus d’argent  est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 22.300 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux (l’habillement, savon, pétrole) et à participer aux évènements sociaux (baptême, mariage et décès). 
Leur ambition est  d’avoir une concession à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The group named Bembeya is made up of four women (one is a widow and three are married). They live with large traditional families. On average they are 39 years old and have 4 children. They live in the Djaka (Kirango) district of Markala (the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know each other through family, by marriage, and through friends and neighbors. They all carry out the same type of revenue-generating business selling fish, in all its forms.

In hopes of improving their business, they decided to approach the Soro Yiriwaso program (Kiva Field Partner). The Bembeya group are currently on their fifth loan, after having repaid the four previous loans on time.

This loan will be used to purchase 16 baskets of fresh fish, 40 blocks of ice (brought in by the transports coming in from Bamako). They buy their fresh fish along the Niger River, one part of which is separated to be dried (either on gravel stones, on hay, or on ‘seccos’). The fish is sold in various forms: fresh fish are sold along the Niger River, in Kirango and in Diamarabougou Markala, sometimes traveling to various districts. The fresh fish is preserved with ice and it is sold in Segou (at the Chateau market) and in Bamako. The dried fish, part of which is set aside to be sold during the shortages and winter months to earn greater revenues, is sold primarily in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin and in the weekly fairs at Segou. The sales are usually completed in cash and the clientele is the general public

They hope to earn average monthly revenues of 22.300 FCFA that will help to provide for the needs of their family (clothing, soap, fuel) and to participate in social events (baptisms, weddings, and funerals).

Their hope is to have a house.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fish.

loans.name: María Rosario

texts.es: María Rosario S. S. de 32 años de edad, reside en Sacacoyo en el departamento de La Libertad. Para María ha sido muy difícil sacar a su familia adelante, ella es madre soltera de dos niños menores de edad, a quien María como mucho sacrificios ha logrado darle un techo seguro. María se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo, lo que ofrece casa por casa  de manera ambulante, pero su principal desempeño es el que hace como fotógrafa a domicilio, para todo tipo de evento. Ella solicita un crédito para invertir en accesorios para su cámara y así lograr mejores resultados en sus fotografías deseadas.
texts.en:
María Rosario S. S., 32 years old, lives in Sacacoyo in the department of La Libertad. For María, it has been hard to bring up her family, as she is a single mother of two small children. María has sacrificed a lot to provide them with a secure home.

María works selling catalog beauty products door-to-door. However, her main business is as a photographer in people’s homes. She takes photographs at all types of events. María is asking for a loan to invest in accessories for her camera, and in this way achieve better results in her photographs.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Camera accessories

loans.name: Rosa Margarita

texts.es: Rosa Margarita C. D. M. resiD. en el municipio D. Ciudad Arce del departamento D. La Libertad. Rosa tiene 31 años D. edad vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos D. 4 años y 18 meses D. edad. Rosa se dedica a la venta D. ropa, que la comercializa con amigos y vecinos, el deseo D. Rosa es poder montar formalmente un negocio donD. pueda ser conocida por muchos clientes, pero para esto necesita D. tu crédito, que le ayudara a consolidar su negocio y así poder crecer económicamente con su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa Margarita C. D. M. lives in the town of Ciudad Arce in the department of La Libertad. Rosa is 31 years-old and lives with her husband and their two children, 4 years and 18 months old. Rosa works selling clothes to her friends and neighbors. Rosa wishes to be able to formally create a business in which she can attract more customers. To accomplish this goal, Rosa needs this loan, which will help her to consolidate her business and thus allow it to grow economically, helping her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabali est composé de cinq femmes, toutes mariées dont trois dans des ménages monogames. Elles sont âgées en moyenne de 28 ans, ont en moyenne 3 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Djaka (Kirango) de  Markala (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié, et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes  membres de l’association traditionnelle « Traoré Ton » qui donna son nom  à leur actuelle association. Elles font exclusivement le commerce de poisson, sous toutes ses formes 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles, elles décidèrent  d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Le groupe Sabali est à son cinquième prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les  quatre précédents prêts
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 30 paniers de poisson frais et 50 barres  de glace (fournies par les transporteurs venant de Bamako). Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger, qui est trié, une  partie de ce poisson est séchée (soit sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos »).Le poisson se vend sous toutes ses formes: les poissons frais se vendent sur place au bord du fleuve Niger,  à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala parfois en ambulant dans les quartiers, le frais  conservé dans de la glace se vend à Ségou (au marché château) et  Bamako, le poisson séché dont une partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue et à l’hivernage où elles gagnent plus d’argent  est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, le poisson fumé est essentiellement vendu à Ségou. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 40.000 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux et à participer aux évènements sociaux (baptême, mariage et décès). 
Leur ambition est  d’acheter du bétail  dont les mâles seront vendus petit à petit pour construire une concession à usage d’habitation, une façon d’assurer l’avenir des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Sabali is composed of five women, all married, of whom three are from monogamous households.  The women average 28 years of age and 3 children each and live in the Djaka district (Kirango) of Markala (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, friendship, and community.  They are all members of the traditional association "Traoré Ton", which lends its name to their current association.  The group members do commerce exclusively in fish, in all its forms.  In order to satisfy the needs of their customers, the women decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their fifth solidarity loan after having repaid the four previous loans.  This new loan will be used to buy 30 baskets of fresh fish and 50 bars of ice (furnished by transporters coming from Bamako).  Supplies of fresh fish are gotten on the banks of the Niger Rivers.  The fish is sorted, and a portion is dried (either on gravel or on straw or on seccos).  The fish is sold in all forms:  the fresh fish is sold locally on the banks of the Niger River, in Kirango, and in Diamarabougou Markala, sometimes door-to-door in the districts.  The fresh fish kept on ice is sold in Ségou (at the Château Market) and in Bamako.  The dried fish (part of which is reserved until the waters recede and until the off-season when the women earn more money) is sold especially in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin, and at the weekly fair of Ségou.  The smoked fish is essentially sold in Ségou.   Sales are made generally in cash to customers composed of women and men. The group members plan on realizing an average monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA that will be used to cover sundry family needs and to assist with societal events (baptisms, marriages, funerals).  Their ambition is to buy livestock, of which the males will be sold over time in order to build a concession in which to live.  This is a way to ensure the children's future.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: Gilma

texts.es: Gilma G. D. N. resiD. en Metapan en el departamento D. Santa Ana, vive con su esposo quien es agricultor y dos hijos D. 7 y 6 años D. edad. El motor D. arranque en Gilma es gracias su esposo, quien la apoyado en las decisiones que ella dese, Gilma ha instalado en su domicilio , su negocio donD. ofrece variedad D. productos para el hogar, el deseo D. ella es seguir surtiendo su tienda y así poder obtener mayores ganancias, que son D. gran utilidad para ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Gilma G. D. N. lives in Metapan in the department of Santa Ana. She lives with her husband, who is a farmer, and their two children ages 6 and 7. Gilma's initial start was in part thanks to her husband, who has supported her in all her decisions. Gilma has installed her business in her home where she offers a variety of household products. Her wish now is to continue expanding her merchandise and thus be able to earn more money, which would help her and her family a lot.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock/expand retail business

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Estella D. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking flour.

Estella is 26 years old and is married to a peasant farmer. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.


About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more baking flour

loans.name: Reina

texts.es: Reina P. P. D. O. resiD. en el occidente del país en el departamento D. Morazán. Reina tienen 36 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos D. 18, 17, 13 y 10 años D. edad. Rosa tiene poco tiempo D. haber comenzado con su negocio, donD. invirtió todo lo ahorrado que tenia ella y su esposo, la tienda D. Reina tiene mucha demanda, razón por la cual Reina se ve en la necesidad D. surtir su negocio y así poder mejorar sus ventas, ya que hay muchos productos D. los cuales carece su negocio.
texts.en:
Reina P. P. D. O. lives in the western part of the country in the department of Morazán. Reina is 36 years-old and lives with her husband and their four children, ages 10, 13, 17, and 18. Rosa has only just started her business, in which she has invested all the money she and her husband had saved. Reina's store has a lot of demand, and for this reason she sees the need to stock and expand the business. Doing this will improve her sales, as there are many products that her store currently lacks.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock/expand retail store

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en: Ayuba N. is currently in the business of selling beer at her home and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Ayuba is 35 years old and is widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Juana Francisca

texts.es: Juana Francisca B. D. P. D. 42 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. San Salvador con su familia que está compuesta por su esposo y sus tres hijos todos estudiantes. Juana es una mujer que le pone mucho entusiasmo a todo lo que hace, a pesar que son tantos años en su negocio, ella manifiesta que lo hace con agrado ya que reconoce que gracias a su tortillería a logrado ayudar a su esposo a sacar adelante a sus hijos, son quince años los que tiene Juana al frete D. su negocio, mismos que ahora desea reactivar a través D. tu ayuda, otorgándolo este crédito, ya que Juana comprara mayor cantidad D. materia prima para distribuir sus tortillas.
texts.en:
Juana Francisca B. D. P. is 42 years-old and lives in the department of San Salvador with her family, maD. up by her husband and their three children, who are all students. Juana is a woman who is very enthusiastic about everything she does. Even after so many years working in her business, she maintains that she still does it gladly, as she recognizes that thanks to her tortilla shop she has been able to help her husband get their kids ahead. For fifteen years Juana has been at the helm of her business, and now she wants to revive it with your help and this loan. With the funds Juana will buy more raw material to make and distribute her tortillas.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for her business

loans.name: Gale

texts.en: Gale E. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials. Gale is 20 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more brewing materials

loans.name: Amadeo

texts.es: Amadeo P. P. reside en el municipio de Soyapango del departamento de San Salvador. Con 43 años de edad Amadeo es un hombre casado,  vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos quienes son el orgullo de Amadeo, su hijo mayor de 19 años de edad es estudiante de Chef y su otro hijo de 15 años de edad, estudiante de bachillerato. Hace once años Amadeo inicio con su negocio, una tienda de productos de consumo, donde recibe el apoyo de su esposa para atender el negocio, el deseo de Amadeo es poder surtir su negocio, con variedad de productos que le permitan seguir aumentando sus ventas y es para ello que solicita de tu crédito.
texts.en:
Amadeo P. P. lives in the Soyapango municipality in the department of San Salvador. With 43 years of age, Amadeo is a married man and lives with his wife and two children who are his pride and joy. His oldest son is 19 years old and is studying to be a chef and his other son who is 15 is in high school. Eleven years ago, Amadeo began his business, a store with essential goods. With the support of his wife he is able to take care of the business. Amadeo’s dream is to stock his business with a variety of products that will allow him to keep increasing his sales; because of this he needs the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock his business.

loans.name: Alponia

texts.en: Alponia K. is currently in the business of selling beer and soda at her bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Alponia is 35 years old and is married to a fisherman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Poni

texts.en: Poni H. is currently in the business of selling maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase rice, pulses (peas, beans or lentils), beans, etc., to sell. Poni is 40 years old and is widowed. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for her goods. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase rice, pulses, beans, etc., to sell

loans.name: Dina Esmeralda

texts.es: Dina Esmeralda D. D. H. D. 35 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. La Libertad. Dina vive con su esposo quien se dedica a trabajar como albañil y agricultor, y sus tres hijos D. 13, 10 y 7 años D. edad. Dina inicio con su negocio a raíz D. la inestabilidad D. los trabajos D. su esposo y sueldos pocos remunerados,  Dina instalo una venta D. tortillas a las afueras D. su casa, donD. actualmente ya es muy conocida en la zona y desea seguir ampliando su negocio, para ello es el destino del crédito que solicita.
texts.en:
Dina Esmeralda D. D. H. is 35 years old, and lives in La Libertad department. Dina lives with her husband who works as a mason and farmer and their three children of 13, 10 and 7 years of age. She began her business because of her husband’s instability in his jobs and the low wages. Dina set up a tortilla shop near her home, where she is very well known in the area. She needs the loan, as she wishes to keep growing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw material for the sale of tortillas.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan E. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase and stock more rice, beans, etc.

Joan is 22 years old. She is married and her husband is a mechanic. She has 2 children and they do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase and stock more rice, beans, etc.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan J. is currently in the business of selling used clothes and sandles. She is requesting a loan to purchase shoes to sell. Susan is 20 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase bedsheets and a sewing machine, etc.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, as well as human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase shoes to sell

loans.name: Ireda Agali One Akor Suzan Group

texts.en: Akor S. is 40 years old. She is a married business woman with three children, all of whom are going to school. In total, she has seven dependents that she is looking after. Akor has been in the produce business for over 10 years. She buys beans, peas, maize flour, etc to sell. She is requesting for the loan because she wants to improve on her capital by expanding her stock and in turn her business. Akor hopes to have at least thirty bags of produce or more for sale. She is a hardworking business woman and her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase stock (produce) for her business.

loans.name: María Ana

texts.es: María Ana M. D. C. resiD. en el departamento D. La Libertad en el municipio D. Colon junto a su esposo. María tiene 51 años D. edad, es una mujer muy entregada muy disciplinada y entregada  a su religión, donD. Dios es su eje principal. María ha manejado su negocio por veinte años, donD. ha ganado una gran clientela a través del paso D. los años, ella tiene su negocio D. venta D. ropa en una calle con mucha afluencia, donD. sus ventas son muy estables, ella ahora solicita D. un crédito que le permita seguir ampliando su negocio, con nueva mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
María Ana M. D. C. lives in the La Libertad department in the Colon municipality with her husband. María is 51 years old and is very dedicated, disciplined, and dedicated to her religion, where God is her main crux. María has managed her business for 20 years, and has gained many customers through the years. She has her business selling clothes on a busy street and her sales are very stable. Now she is requesting a loan to allow her to continue expanding her business, with new merchanchise to offer to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Josh Wilcox, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of new merchandise to invest in her business

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene H. is 25 years old. He is married and has 4 children ages 4 to 8 years old. He also cares for one dependent. Eugene lives Nyamagabe Center where he has a variety shop. He employs 2 people in his business and his shop is open from 7 AM to 6 PM every day.

After having operated his business successfully for 3 years, he is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He wants to expand his shop and buy additional goods, such as household staples and housewares, that he hopes will appeal to his current customers and attract new customers. All of these changes should result in a greater profit for his enterprise. With this profit, Eugene will pay his children's school fees and continue to build a secure future for his young family.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, bath products, and housewares

loans.name: Lidia Marina

texts.es: Lidia Marina C. reside en el departamento de La Paz. Lidia tiene 44 años de edad es madre soltera y vive con su dos hijos Wilfredo de 22 años de edad, quien es empleado y Claudia de 19 años de edad, estudiante de bachillerato. Lidia es una persona muy trabajadora y alegre, maneja su negocio con gran entusiasmo, ella posee una venta de tortillas y pupusas desde la cochera de su casa, donde sus ventas son estables, el crédito que solicita ahora Lidia es para poder incrementar la producción de sus productos, pero para ello necesita comprar mayor cantidad de materia prima.
texts.en:
Lidia Marina C. lives in the department of La Paz. She is 44 years old and lives with her two children: Wilfred, 22, is employed, and Claudia, 19, is a student.

Lidia makes and sells tortillas and pupusas in the garage of her home. She is hardworking and cheerful, and manages her business with great enthusiasm. This loan is for the purchase of larger quantities of wholesale foods, which will allow her to increase production.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wholesale foods for making tortillas and pupusas

loans.name: Alexis

texts.en:
Alexis R. is 27 years old and single. He lives in Nyarugura Center, which is approximately a 3-hour drive from Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.  Alexis has had his own variety store since he was just 21 years old. Today he employs two people to help him run his business. His store is open from 6 AM to 9 PM every day.

Although Alexis has been in the business for 6 years, his capital reserves are still too low to expand his shop. He believes that a small amount of additional capital would allow him to expand his business by purchasing some new goods to sell. His sense of the market is that his current customers will respond well to these new offerings and he may also attract new clients.  He believes his strategy will be a profitable one and is looking for funding and loan investors. Alexis is, therefore, requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company.

loans.use: A variety inventory/goods

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan has been the owner of a car painting shop since 1994, by which he earns income to help satisfy the needs of his family. He is a married man with four children who are still in school. Hassan is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy additional tools needed to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy additional tools

loans.name: Elias

texts.en: Elias has owned a bird shop since 2005 in his town because he really loves raising birds. He is a 31-year-old married man with three children. Elias is applying for a loan of $1,200 to purchase food and cages for the birds.

loans.use: To purchase bird food and cages

loans.name: Mable's Group

texts.en:
Mable M. has been running a secondhand clothing sales business for six years and generally generates 30,000 Ugandan shillings per week in profits. She is married with four children, all enrolled in school, and she is the leader of her group in Ntungamo.

Currently Mable travels to several markets a week to sell her inventory. She believes that, with the continued success of her business, one day she will be able to set up a proper store and will no longer have to travel so much. She dreams of one day being able to help in the fight against HIV/AIDS that so devastates her country of Uganda.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Fadi has been working as a fisherman since 1999. He is a 33 year old single man. He works hard in collaboration with his father to provide better living conditions for his mother and four brothers. Today, Fadi is asking for a loan of $800 to perform maintenance on his boat motor and buy more tools to better satisfy the needs of his business.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his boat motor

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh is a 36 year old married woman with three children. Since 2006, she has been working in the agriculture sector, as a farmer, to help her husband with the household expenses. Today, Fatmeh is requesting a loan of $500 to renovate the irrigation system. This will enable her to expand her business by growing more products, thereby making a good income for her family.

loans.use: To renovate the irrigation system

loans.name: Veneranda

texts.en:
Veneranda N. is 30 years old and married. She has 4 children. Veneranda lives in Nyaruguru in Gikongoro Province. For 7 years, she has had her own successful kiosk where she sells a variety of goods -- most food. Veneranda's business requires that she works from 7 AM to 6 PM every day.

Veneranda is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders through Vision Finance Company. She hopes to expand her business by purchasing large quantities of flour and bread-making supplies so that she can produce sumptuous baked goods. With this additional source of business, Veneranda hopes to generate more profits. If successful, this bread-making strategy will help her to pay the school fees for her children and provide more and better food for her family. In addition, she and her devoted husband will be more able to buy the home of their own that they have long dreamed of owning.

loans.use: Flour and breadmaking supplies

loans.name: Justus' Group

texts.en: R. Justus is 75 years old and is married with seven children. He is the leader of his group Rukungiri. Five of his children have university degrees and the other two are soldiers in the Ugandan army. R.’s business specializes in grazing and crop husbandry and generates 250,000 USH in profits per week. He has worked very hard to achieve his success, starting out as a simple shopkeeper and responsibly saving any money he made. R. would like to use the requested loan amount to buy bulls and fertilizers. His dream is to one day be able to purchase a modern farm. Additionally, he hopes to maintain a stable family life.

loans.use: To purchase bulls and fertilizers

loans.name: Juvenal

texts.en:
Juvenal N. is 34 years old and single. He lives in Nyamagabe, which is approximately a 3-hour drive from Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. Juvenal has a successful, small, local grocery store where he sells a variety of goods to a loyal customer base. This is his 3rd year in the grocery business and he employs one person as a helper. His store requires that he work from 6 AM to 7 PM every day. Juvenal enjoys his life as a self-employed man with a successful business.

Juvenal is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He wants to expand his grocery business by purchasing some additional inventory, such as jam, sodas, juices, and delicious breads. With the sale of additional goods and his improved capital situation, Juvenal will strengthen his business and begin to build a more secure future for himself and his (eventual...hopeful!) family.

loans.use: To expand his general inventory and buy jams,margarine, fruit juice and a variety of bakery products

loans.name: Mbacke

texts.fr:
Madame Macke S.  est une  femme mariée âgée de 45 ans qui a longtemps adhère a la caisse de Baye Laye a Guediawaye.Son activité est orientée vers le commerce de produits divers et elle a déjà bénéficie de quatre prêts  antérieurs.  C’est une femme soutien de famille car elle a quatre enfants dont l âge varie entre six et vingt six ans. Elle a aussi quatre autres personnes en charge. Son activité principale est la vente de tissus mais elle gère aussi deux frigos, l’un pour vendre de la glace et des jus et l’autre pour satisfaire la demande de la clientèle en conservation de poissons et de viande. Compte tenu de sa situation sociale et de son statut de femme mariée  c’est surtout l’aspect lucratif qui l’a pousse à choisir  cet activité ce qui  lui permet en même temps de gérer son foyer. La  période de veille de fêtes est très intéressante pour elle car elle parvient à écouler beaucoup de marchandises  et accroitre ses bénéfices. 

Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs pour acheter des tissus en vue de renforcer son activité de couture mais aussi acheter un moteur pour remplacer celui du deuxième frigo qui est en panne depuis un  certain temps.  Elle envisage de voyager dans la sous région et pourquoi  pas souhaiter aller à Doubaï -  situe aux Emirats  Unis - la ou la plupart des grands commerçants se procurent leurs marchandises. Les  moyens de son mari étant  très limites, son prêt  lui a permis ,avec l’accroissement de ses bénéfices, de financer ses quelques besoins personnels et d’ assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Madame Macke S. is a 45-year old married woman who has been involved with the Baye Laye credit union in Guediawaye for a long time already. She has already had 4 previous loans. She helps support her 4 children (aged 6 to 26) and four other people. Her primary business is selling fabrics, but she also sells ice cream and juices, and provides refrigerated storage of fish and meat for her clients. This work allows her to manager her family household as well as earn a living. The upcoming pre-holiday perioid is very important for Mme. S., because she usually sells a lot of merchandise. She asks for a loan of 500,000 XOF to purchase fabric for her fashion business, and also to purchase a new engine for her second fridge as it hasn't been working for some time now. Some day, she would like to travel in the sub-region, and maybe even go to Dubai in the United Arab Emirates, where all the big merchants get their merchandise. Since her husband has very limited resources, the loans have allowed her to increase her income to help pay for her personal needs and assure that her children can attend school.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: renforcement fond de roulement

loans.name: Jerome

texts.en:
Jerome N. is 22 years old and single. He lives in Nyarugenge District. Sinc 2004, he has had a shop where he sells a variety of new shoes. He employs one person in his successful business. His work requires that he be at the store from 7 AM to 6 PM every day. 

Jerome is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders through Vision Finance Company. He hopes to expand his business by extending into another product line, women's handbags, which he believes will be successful and demanded by his current and future customers. With this new business, Jerome hopes to get more profits, which in turn, will help him to build his business and and a more secure future for himself.

loans.use: To buy women's handbags to sell in his shoe store

loans.name: Diane

texts.en:
Diane M. is 43 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children, ages 22 to 9 years, and she also takes care of 7 dependents. This hardworking woman lives in Kicukiro, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. Diane has not been in business for very long -- she started selling milk in 2007 -- and today she employs one person as a helper. Her business requires that she works from 6 AM to 8 PM every day.

Diane is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing more milk and supplies to sell to her growing customer base. With this loan, Diane will be able to better take care of her children and the dependents that are in her care.

loans.use: Milk and supplies

loans.name: Marthe

texts.en:
Marthe N. is 48 years old. She is married and has 8 children between the ages of 10 to 25 years old. She lives in the Northern Province of Rwanda where she has sold potatoes for the past 4 years. She employs 3 people from her community in her business. Her business requires that she work from 8 AM to 4 PM every day. 

Marthe is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. She wants to purchase larger quantities of potatoes at lower prices due to greater volume. With this loan, Marthe hopes to attract more customers to her shop and, hopefully, to earn more profit in the process. This, in turn, will allow her and her devoted husband to build a more secure future for their family.

loans.use: To buy potatoes in bulk

loans.name: Francis Kundu

texts.en:
Francis is 52 years old, married and is blessed with two children. His retail business is located at Mugunga market in Eldoret. Wanting to enhance his business, Francis sought out a KADET branch and applied for a loan. With this loan, Francis is planning to add more stock to his shop, which includes buying foodstuffs (unga flour), cooking fat, sugar and rice. Also he intends to start farming so that he can provide for the basic needs for the family. His future dream is to buy a plot of land and be able to build residential and rental houses.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: http://www.kadet.co.ke/

loans.use: To purchase items including flour, cooking fat, sugar and rice to sell

loans.name: Josepha

texts.en:
Josepha N. is 41 years old. She is married and has 3 children, ages 8 to 15 years old. Josepha lives in the Northern Province of Rwanda, which is approximately 3 hours drive from Kigali, the capital city. Josepha owns and operates a business where she sells a great variety of goods. She would like to add handbags to her offering.  A proven entrepreneur, this is her tenth year in this business and she employs four people from her community. Her business requires that she works from 6 AM to 6 PM every day.

Josepha is a seasoned businesswoman. She is requesting her second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase handbags to sell. It should be noted that her first loan was paid on time and in full. The success of her business, partially enabled through this loan, continues to help her to build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: More inventory, specifically handbags

loans.name: Achwak

texts.en: Achwak is a 25-year-old married woman with 3 young children. In 2005, she decided to open an evening dresses shop in her town. Today, Achwak is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase additional dresses. She is well known by the neighboring villages, so, with this loan, she can increase her sales and her income.

loans.use: To purchase additional dresses

loans.name: Bonface

texts.en:
Bonface is a 27-year-old married businessman. His business is located at Eldoret in the Rift Valley Province of Kenya.

Bonface runs a store where he sells cooking fat, flour, washing soap, and calling cards, and provides calling services. Bonface sought out a KADET branch and applied for a loan. He intends to use the loan to improve his business by increasing his stock of items. His future plan is to improve his entire business, specifically his M-PESA phone services.

About KADET: 	
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his retail business

loans.name: Hanaa

texts.en: Hanaa is a married woman with one child. She is 42-year-old. She has been working in home-based food production since 2000. She produces food when her client's request it. Hanaa is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more merchandise, because the demand for her products is good.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad has been working as a taxi driver since 2002. He is a 40-year-old married man. He provides transportation to the neighboring villages. Ahmad is applying for a loan of $1,000 to perform maintenance on his car's motor.

loans.use: To repair the motor of his taxi

loans.name: Raed

texts.en: Raed is a 24-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He has owned a barber shop since 2002 called “Al Read" where he services the neighboring villages. Today, Raed is asking for a loan of $1,000. With the loan, he will buy new tools and new chairs to attract more clients to his shop.

loans.use: To buy tools and chairs for his barber shop

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou D. est une ancienne sociétaire de la caisse de Baye laye,une femme qui a atteint le troisième age mais très dynamique qui a initie ses enfants a ses activités et qui a presque fait adhérer tous ses enfants.Elle a cinq enfants presque tous majeurs et cinq autres personnes en charges.Son activité principale est la transformation de céréales locales qu'elle a exerce pendant trois ans.Elle évolue aussi dans l'élevage de bovins et l'aviculture pendant dix ans.Elle a longtemps évolue dans le développement sociale et a eu a faire beaucoup d'actions sociales en aidant certains démunis jusqu'à avoir le gout du métier.Ses revenus mensuels varient entre 854 000 frs et 1 154 000 frs.L'accroissement de ses bénéfices lui permettent de diversifier ses produits et services commercialises et de mieux supporter les charges familiales.Elle vit avec son mari ,un navigateur en retraite.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou D., a former member of the branch office of Baye Laye, is a woman who has reached her sunset year, though she is very energetic.  She has introduced her children to her businesses and has almost gotten all of her children to join in.  She has five children, almost all of them adults, plus she has five other people in her care.  Her principal business is processing local grains, something she has been doing for three years.  She has also been developing her businesses raising cattle and poultry for ten years.  For quite awhile, she has made advances in societal development and has acted many times socially by helping certain disadvantaged people to enjoy having a trade.  Her monthly revenues vary from 854,000 to 1,154,000 francs.  The growth in her profits enables her to diversify her commercialized goods and services and to cover family expenses better.  She lives with her husband, a retired navigator.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a single man who lives with his parents and one brother. He has owned a barber shop called "Barhoum' in his town since 1996 and he has been involved in this market for 15 years. Today, Ibrahim is requesting a loan of $900 to purchase a specialized sterilizer machine for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase a specialized sterilizer machine

loans.name: Asad

texts.en: Asad has owned a car repair shop since 2000. From this shop, he earns an income to satisfy the needs of his family. He supports his wife and child with this business. He is 32 years old. Asad is requesting a loan of $ 1,200 to purchase an air compressor for his business so he can meet the demands of his clients.

loans.use: To purchase an air compressor

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
La señora Virginia Z. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Tembladerani, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo y sus tres hijos.
La señora Virginia es comerciante de productos como licuadoras, edredones, chompas, sabanas, que ofrece principalmente en oficinas de la ciudad y su esposo es empleado de una oficina pública de esta ciudad, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para aumentar los productos que la señora Virginia ofrece e incrementar sus ingresos por el fin de año.
Esta es la sexta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mrs. Virginia Z. lives in her own house in the Tembladerani zone, west of the City of La Paz, with her husband and her 3 children. Virginia is a merchant of products such as blenders, eiderdowns, sweaters, and sheets, offered principally in city offices. Her husband is employed in a public office of this city. Their family is maintained by their incomes.

The solicited loan is to augment the products that Virginia offers and to increase their incomes for the end of the year.

This is the sixth time they have solicited a loan and the socioeconomic analysis carried out qualifies them favorably, granting access to the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY PRODUCTS SUCH AS BLENDERS, EIDERDOWNS, SWEATERS, AND SHEETS TO SELL

loans.name: Moises

texts.es:
El señor Moisés W.  vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Faro Murillo, área periférica de la ciudad de La Paz, con sus tres hijos pues su esposa falleció hace dos años.
El señor Moisés tiene un puesto de reparadora de calzados en un mercado de esta ciudad, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la refacción del muro perimetral de su casa, que por su antigüedad se encuentra deteriorado y esta por caer.
Esta es la segunda vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Moisés Karachi lives in his own house in the Faro Murillo area, which is outside the city of La Paz. He lives with his three children. His wife died three years ago. He has a shoe repair stand in the market in this city. This income supports his family. The loan he is asking for is to repair the walls of his house. Due to the aged structure, the walls have deteriorated and at risk of falling. This is the second time he has asked for a loan. The socioeconomic analysis favorably qualifies him, and he is able to accept a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair the walls of his house

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
El señor Oscar A. vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  de Sopocachi, de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Oscar es empleado de una empresa de construcción de esta ciudad, ingresos con los que se mantiene.
El crédito solicitado es para la conclusión de la construcción de tres habitaciones que actualmente se encuentra en obra gruesa, para así habitar la vivienda.
Esta es la primera vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Oscar A. lives in his parents’ house in the Sopocachi area of the city of La Paz. Oscar works for a construction company in this city. He supports himself with this income. The loan that he is asking for is to finish building three rooms, which are currently roughly built. He wants to finish them to live in the house. This is the first time he has asked for a loan. The socioeconomic analysis favorably qualifies him and he is able to accept a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build three rooms in his parents' house

loans.name: Christian

texts.es:
Christian C. vive en casa de sus tíos, en la zona  de pasankeri, de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Christian atiende un punto Internet en su mismo domicilio, ingresos con los que se mantiene.
El crédito solicitado es para la actualización de las computadoras con las que brinda el servicio de Internet.
Esta es la cuarta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Chrisitan C. lives in his aunt and uncle’s house in the Pasankeri area of the city of La Paz. Christian tends an Internet café in his home. He supports himself with this income. The loan he is asking for is to update the computers with Internet service. This is the fourth time he has asked for a loan. The socioeconomic analysis favorably qualifies him and he is able to accept a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To maintain and update the computers that he has in his Internet cafe

loans.name: Petrona Maritza

texts.es: La señora Petrona es una mujer de recursos bajos, desde su juventud  ayudaba a sus padres ya que eran familia humilde de casos recursos, tiene 46 años de edad, con tres hijos los cuales los tiene estudiando para que tengan un mejor futuro, es casada y su esposo trabaja en mantenimiento, viven en un barrio muy pobre donde la delincuencia asecha cada día, por el poco desempleo en Nicaragua. Ella desde hace diez años trabaja como domestica donde gana un salario bajo,  y no le permite proyectarse con sus objetivos de terminar su casa, en tiempos libre ella lava y plancha para obtener otros ingresos y poder cubrir las necesidades en la alimentación ya que la canasta básica esta súper cara y no ajusta con su salario. Lleva cocho ciclo en Afodenic y gracias a los financiamientos ha logrado hacer las mejoras, con el préstamo anterior compro piedra, arena, hierro pero no logro hacer nada lo cual con este préstamo podrá comenzar a cambiar el techo que esta muy viejo y se pasa el agua y hacer las mejora. Agrádese a la institución por dar la oportunidad que da a mujeres pobres para que logren mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Petrona has few resources. Since she was young she helped her parents. They were a humble family with scant resources. She is 46, and she has three children who are studying so that they can have a better future. She is married, and her husband works in maintenance. They live in a very poor neighborhood, which is threatened with violence everyday because of unemployment in Nicaragua. Since she was ten years old, she has worked as a domestic employee, where she earns a low salary. This does not allow her to work towards her objective of finishing her house. In her free time she washes and irons to get other income to be able to cover the food necessities. The basic necessities are super expensive, and they do not match her salary. She has had eight cycles with Afodenic. Thanks to the loans she has been able to make improvements. With the previous loan she bought stones, sand, and iron. But, she was not able to do anything. With this loan she will start to change the roof, which is very old and leaks, and make the improvement. She is grateful to the institution for giving poor women the opportunity to improve their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zince to change the very old roof on her house

loans.name: Amy

texts.fr: Amy N. est une sociétaire de Baye Laye Guediawaye  qui évolue dans le commerce de chaussures d’hommes et de femmes .Elle exerce aussi la vente de diner le soir (lakh,dakhine),de petit  déjeuner le matin. Elle est mariée, mère de deux enfants dont l’âge varie entre cinq ans et huit ans. Elle a aussi en charge deux autres personnes. Son mari  est chauffeur, et elle capitalise deux ans d’expérience dans son activité de commerce. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs  dans l’espoir d’augmenter sa capacité de production surtout au niveau de la vente de chaussures qui s’avère plus lucrative.Qvec ce crédit elle espère augmenter ses bénéfices mensuels de 25 000 frs diversifier ses produits  en incorporant la vente de chaussures de femmes et sacs a mains .Elle souhaite aussi renforcer son épargne  pour pouvoir améliorer les conditions alimentaires de sa famille.
texts.en:
Amy N. is a member of Baye Laye Guediawaye and is advancing in her commerce selling shoes for men and women.  She also works at selling dinner in the evenings: lakh (millet and fermented milk) and dakhine (lamb stew). And she sells breakfast in the mornings.  She is married and the mother of two children, aged 5 and 8 years.  She also has two other people in her care.  Her husband is a chauffeur. And she capitalizes on two years of experience in her commercial work.  She's requesting a loan of 500,000 francs in hopes of increasing her production capacity, especially in selling shoes, which is turning out to be more lucrative.  With this loan, she hopes to increase her monthly profits by 25,000 francs and to diversify her goods by incorporating the sale of women's shoes and handbags.  She also wishes to bolster her savings to be able to improve her family's food situation.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital
